Even though the pan is well seasoned at the factory I followed the directions for seasoning myself and then promptly used it. Wow, It's great. I not only used it to make the baby dutch pancakes and cornbread I got it for but now I'm using for many other things too. If you eat meat there is no better way to cook a steak than to sear it in this pan and finish the cooking in a preheated oven. Cleaning it is easy as the seasoning really makes it a non-stick pan. The handle actually works well with the pan even though it looks too short.
title: Can't go wrong with this pan.

author: Mary Mary
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2018
review_content: This is a great little cast-iron skillet. It heats evenly and quickly, and cleans up beautifully. The food doesn't stick to it at all.  I just seasoned it before using it the first time; and then, after each use, season it again with either olive or vegetable oil after washing and drying it. Seasoning, for those who are new to this, is just putting a small amount of oil inside the pan and spreading it around with a paper towel or napkin to give it a light coating...that's it.  The cast iron is fine on your Corelle cook top; it does not scratch or damage the cook top; I know because that is the cook top I have.  This 6-1/2 inch size is perfect for 1 or 2 eggs, a toasted cheese sandwich, a pork chop, etc., or for cooking and sauteing things to be added to other dishes you may be preparing. I couldn't be happier with this Lodge iron skillet. I bought this small size to give cooking with an iron skillet a try, and now I am sold on them. I plan to buy another in the 10" or larger size but will only buy the Lodge because it has proven to be great for me.  There is a hint of iron taste at first, but that is one of the reasons for an iron skillet - adding iron to your diet. That taste has dissipated with use, though, but you still have that iron added to your food.  Price: Amazon always has the best prices. I don't think this is returnable though. You may want to check that if you prefer that option.  At the price I paid as an add-on item of a little over $8, I wasn't concerned about that.  Happy I bought it.
title: THIS LITTLE "LODGE" SKILLET IS GREAT/LOVE IT!

author: Freddie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2021
review_content: I just tested out my new Lodge 6.5” cast iron frying pan.I bought this little frying pan because I want to use it for a camping trip I’m planning.  I I have experimented with my camping menu and have discovered that although freeze dried foods like Mountain House, Alpine Aire, etc., are good for many things, the problem is with eggs.  Freeze dried eggs simply don’t cut it.  That’s why I bought this little cast iron frying pan, because eggs need to be cooked on the spot.  As I will only need to prepare single servings for myself, this 6.5” size seemed to be the answer.So, I started by seasoning my new pan.Martha Stewart recommends using Crisco shortening to season the pan.  She says that a vegetable oil that is solid at room temperature works best, so, trusting Martha, that’s what I used.  Here’s how I did it.1) I thoroughly washed the new pan with hot water and dish washing detergent.2) Dried the pan thoroughly by wiping it off and then by placing it for several minutes in a preheated oven at 200°.3) Coated the pan thoroughly with Crisco (including the handle).4) Placed the pan upside down on the middle oven rack and heated it to 450° for one hour.5) Allowed the pan to cool down for one and a half hours.Now to cook an experimental breakfast!I have read reviews that eggs will stick!  (Extra cleaning chores are inconvenient on a camping trip)I decided to begin with two slices of Spam.The 6.5” pan size will hold exactly two slices of Spam……...so far, so good.And it cooked them just fine in a little margarine.Now for the eggs.I was curious to find out if the 6.5” size would handle 3 eggs; scrambled.A little more margarine into the pan, then pour them (pre-mixed up) into the pan.This little pan EASILY handles 3 eggs!And as I scrambled them in the pan I could see that the pan seasoning was doing it’s job very well.NO sticking!Excellent!Clean up was a breeze.Don’t wash cast iron in water!Just wipe it out and then re-oil it with a bit more Crisco.Bottomline; mission accomplished!This little cast iron skillet works perfectly for my intended purpose.  To cook up a quick breakfast of a couple slices of Spam and 3 scrambled eggs.  And then to clean up without effort..........very happy!
title: Works Perfectly!

author: Glitter Is Life
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2018
review_content: Picked up this little 8" skillet after finally throwing in the towel on non-stick pans altogether. I figured with enough diligent seasoning I could make this my designated omelette pan. Well, imagine my surprise when I rushed things a bit and decided to test-fry an egg after only two coats of seasoning and that sucker slid around like it was on black ice!I know some people advocate sanding down Lodge's rugged finish, but, I have several pieces and have never found this to be necessary. You want at least a little texture to help that seasoning cling. FWIW, this one didn't have any egregious burrs or pits on the interior surface, so perhaps that had something to do with it, but I must have amazing luck, because 2-4 coats of extra virgin coconut oil seasoning oven-baked on high heat has worked for all five of my pieces (3 skillets & 2 dutch ovens), making them ready for anything. Even eggs and fish!Oh, and yeah, this thing is perfect for a flawlessly executed 2-egg omelette with some gloriously crispy edges. I couldn't be happier!Now if only I loved Lodge's Carbon Steel pans as much...
title: Affordable, Dependable Kitchen Classic.

author: Jeff Kletsky
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2020
review_content: Things for Lodge have somehow gone even further downhill. I know this isn't the Lodge of even the post-war era, but that is is even worse than that of the early 2000s is surprising. With a parrot in the house, we needed to replace our non-stick cookware. With years of experience in using cast iron, these moderately priced Lodge pans seemed a good option -- until they arrived.The cooking surface is so rough that it is unusable, even with proper seasoning. Read up on it, you can't smooth it out as apparently it won't take seasoning if you do any more that remove the sharp points of the rough surface.Soy oil is used for seasoning, which for those with allergies or sensitivities is beyond problematic. The seasoning can't be removed with any reasonable cleaning approach used for cast iron.There's a reason Lodge acquired Finex this year, apparently they either or both can't manufacture a quality product, or their brand's value has plummeted so far as to be unrecoverable.Do yourself a favor, buy a https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00076QWTA/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 or similar if you're looking for an inexpensive, "seasonable" pan. If you want cast iron, go for a Field or one of its competitors.
title: Unusably rough, seasoned with soy, avoid

author: BGirl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2020
review_content: I have not always had good luck with cast iron so gave up after a few tries.  But I love to cook and like how certain foods turn out in cast iron.  So I gave cast iron one more try and purchased a 10-inch skillet.  I christened it with bacon and then hashbrowns. Crisp outside & tender inside of potatoes reminded me why cast iron is great. Seared steaks and even fried eggs, after I seasoned it a few more times.  It does require just a little special effort but it's not that bad really. I wash it with just a drop or 2 of liquid dish soap, with a soft brush. Rinse and DRY real well. I place it on hot burner for a few mins to make sure all moister evaporates. They pour a just a very little cooking oil or bacon grease on it, rub it on all sides with paper towel until there's just a very thin film, and then I place it in a hot 350 over for 30 mins and turn oven off.  it cools and sits in my oven till the next time I need it.  Just never let it sit in water or moisture, and follow the cleaning steps above, and it gets better each time you use it. After I had used it 3 times and seasoned each time afterwards, I fried eggs on it the 4th time. You want to make sure you always use enough fat or shortening and those eggs did not stick and came out great. Also, while it doesn't distribute heat evenly, it does hold heat.  So the trick is put your clean pan on the heat, wait till it's good and hot (a few drops water sizzle & evaporate right way and it is ready). Now lower your heat to your required setting, add enough oil/butter/shortening of choice, and cook your food.  Fantastic results. Glad I tried cast iron one more time.
title: Best pre-seasoned pan I've tried.

author: RPG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2015
review_content: I am a college student and I bought this to use for camping and then I just started using it in the kitchen and now I use it everyday. I am also looking at getting another one. I did not season this skillet in the oven as other reviewers mentioned. Food did stick to it for the first couple uses, but it scraped off with no particular difficulty. After a few uses I could cook an egg without it sticking at all, with some oil.I now cook everything in this skillet. I even put it right on the table to serve the food in. It looks great and stays hot for a very long time relative to cookware of other materials. I have been using it for about a month and a layer of polymerized oil has build up on the bottom. There is a 1/2 inch ring near the wall of the skillet where there is no built up seasoning yet but it does not seem to affect the nonstick quality.I just use this on an old style heating element on my kitchen stove. It takes 3-4 minutes to heat up. I usually leave it on medium heat to heat up and just leave it on medium. I have researched extensively and I have concluded that soap does not really hurt cast iron. I wash mine with soap and it is still nonstick. I also purchased the Lodge plastic scrapers that I really like.I also like frying things in cast iron. The oil seems to hold its temperature really well which may be why things turn out more crispy than in a regular skillet.
title: I use it everyday now!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Maria Marroquin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2021
review_content: If you are like me and have your hands full with kids, pets, a husband to feed, house chores and then some, do not get a cast iron skillet. At the end of the day I just want to throw everything in the dishwasher and let it do it’s job. The cast iron skillet requires you to scrub the left on food with hot water and an iron abrasive sponge. You also cannot leave it to dry or it will rust. You must dry it right away with a cloth or put it on the burner to heat up and dry. If you do get rust because you forgot to dry it right away, you must remove the rust before you can cook with it again. To remove the rust is a whole other process. Cast iron skillets are not mom friendly. Stick to stainless steel moms. At least till your kids get older so they can help you scrub the rust out of the pan. LOL!
title: High Maintenance

author: Wingnut
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2020
review_content: While I've had good luck with the smaller diameter Lodge brand iron skilets in the past, this 15" model proved to be an EPIC failure. I'm definitely 'old-school', so I've bought, seasoned and utilized these older types of cast iron skilets for well over 60-years, but we repeatedly seasoned and used this one, and it was just a doissster. The quality of the cast iron on this model is dismal! Its way too porous and low-grade. In addition, the heat distribution was pathetic out to the outer margins of the pan. In fact, on only its third use (and at moderate stovetop heat), while making routine fajitas, the very center of the pan overheated, with the metal becoming molten and it literally SAGGED! Absolute fifty-dollars worth of garbage! We have four other Lodge brand cast iron skilrts of smaller diameter, and NONE of them have shown this type of failure. And cleaning it? A virtual nightmare! So I would recommend opting for another brand, or at a minimum, I would suggest avoidance of this largest (15") skilet in favor of two smaller ones.
title: MEH! I'D SUGGEST DOWNSIZING AND DOUBLING-UP TO SAVE YOURSELF SOME MONEY.

author: mike
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2019
review_content: Never used a cast iron pan.  Never realized I had a use for it...  oh did I ever!It's primary purpose was for caramelizing onions with the side burner of the grill, without damaging the pan...  flawless there.Then I found these other recipes that called for using for baking.  Saute and caramelize strawberries in it, set aside to cool, and clean the pan.  Add pancake batter in the pan folding in the strawberries.  Then bake it in the cast iron skillet.Or baking cornbread in it, with bacon or sausage crumbles with cheese in it.  God does it come out good AND it's far less of a mess to clean up than a traditional pan.Now I own 4 of these things in varying sizes for various cooking tasks.  LOVE the old school over this new school crap.
title: how the heck did I wait so long to get one????

author: PITA
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2017
review_content: Been wanting another cast iron pan.  I first bought the 10 inch.  Almost immediately I regretted not getting a bigger one.  I still use the 10 inch but you definitely need a bigger pan if you cook for others and not just yourself.  I needed to brown 3 large pork chops last night and they fit beautifully in this new pan.  The pan could have held a 4th but would have been a tight fit.  I frequently make rack of lamb as Costco sells a great Australian brand that is very affordable.  Searing it in the 10 inch was kind of a pain.  Now that I have the 13.25 inch pan I like it much better.  No matter what you are going to get splatter on your stove top, but the larger pan helps keep more in the pan and not on the stove.  The only thing I don't care for is the weight of the pan.  Even the 10 inch is HEAVY.  I just have to work out more I guess and build up my biceps.  I have to use both hands to lift the 13.25 inch one.  That to me is not a deal breaker but, dang, they are heavy.  It was also important to me that this product is American made.  Big selling point for me every time.  If you have a glass stove top (as we do) you must be careful not to drag or shake the pans on your stove top as the cast iron WILL scratch the glass.  Care is easy as well.  You can give it a quick scrub using cold water and then just wipe it out with a cloth or paper towel.  Never use soap on it.  Sometimes I'll put a tablespoon of kosher salt in the pan as a scrubbing agent.  Make sure to re-season it with oil (I use olive or avocado oil) before putting it away.  It will last you generations.
title: I needed to brown 3 large pork chops last night and they fit beautifully in this new pan

author: Brandon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2021
review_content: These things are easier to clean than aluminum pots with garbage burned on.This isn't rocket science. Don't overthink it. Youtubers already laid out easy instructions. Just re-grease it top and bottom after use and heat it up on the stove to set in. Don't leave it moist. I can't believe how many people are ranting like millenials rust rust rust 1 star review.If it's that hard just go watch a Gen Z review and learn from them. They smarter than a millenial.My first use I tossed in left overs with shredded cheese on top. Yeah it was caked on. I don't have a Lodge Scraper yet, so I used copper scrub pads and lightly got it off really easily in 5 minutes under hot water. Just the water. Dry it down good. Grease it up i used a dash of olive oil, people said they use crisco. Polish it up, heat it on the stove. Call it a day. People 100 years ago didn't need "LIFE HACK" video for common sense. Feels wonderful to use, keep the heat low.If it's that hard to understand probably better to return this FINE Cast Iron Skillet for something more appropriate for Millenials like Nintendo Amibos or My Little Ponies. GG.
title: DO NOT LISTEN TO MILLENIALS COMPLAINING ABOUT RUST

author: D. Monty Jennings
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2018
review_content: My wife has been using this skillet about 3 times a week since she got it. It came oiled & ready to use. She made some stove-top chicken with what they call smashed potatoes which was fantastic. Looked just as fantastic as it taste. I am amazed at all the recipes that are out there online. I think she got this one from Facebook but I assume Amazon probably has recipes somewhere on the site also for free. If I would have known she'd be getting one of these skillets, I would have went garage sailing more this summer since they're usually a buck or 2. I can tell you from a husbands point of view who's not the cooker in the family, guy's, if you are looking for a gift for your wife, get one. You won't be sorry. For you ladies reading this, it's great. You'll be amazed with what you can cook with it & the recipes out there are nothing short of fantastic. I'll post another review with a photo this week I had to fix the errors on this review because I was calling it a pan & not a skillet. I just ordered her a 12 inch skillet with 8 egg/pancake rings I might as well get those accessories since she'll be doing Sunday morning breakfasts again. The egg rings do help you make the eggs all uniform. With our 18 inch X 12 inch electric skillet, she'll be able to cook 8 eggs at a time, which helps out, plus it helps you make a restaurant style egg, without any broken yokes or egg runs where it looks like one gigantic egg, at least when I am elected to cook that's what usually happens. As for using the Egg Rings for Pancakes, our favorite server at our neighborhood restaurant told us that if we can't get the Real Restaurant Pancake Mix, use Sprite or 7-Up in the place of water, when we make our Pancake Mix. Not only will they have a sweet taste but they'll be nice and fluffy too. One more thing, if you like to cook outside on a grill over a log fire out on the pit, there's nothing around that beats a cast iron skillet. Those Teflon coated skillets warp so easy, they can get ruined after just one meal made outdoors & you now how good food taste's when you cook over an open fire.....Dan
title: Back to the old cooking technology, cast iron skillet!

author: D.K
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2019
review_content: Love the Lodge 10.25" cast pan, and especially this Buffalo nickel design.  This is a specialized pan for me.Cornbread period. Nothing else ever. Buffalo means "back the f off, this is for cornbread only".I did a quick reseason on it with bacon grease on the stove top.Have made several cakes so far, wiping the pan down lightly with bacon grease.All came out crispy and perfect.  The cakes seem to vanish out of the oven. A+ Lodge.Wipe pan out with a paper towel and a sprinkle of salt, and youre good till next time.
title: Super pan

author: Chinarut
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2021
review_content: ok - we come from using Le Creuset enameled pans we could throw in the dishwasher so we were super hesitant to try these thinking they would be a nightmare to maintain.  We figured at 1/10 the cost, it was worth a shot - how could we go wrong?  Turns out it’s pretty easy and we ended up getting the smaller 8” pan as well!For the record, Lodge themselves say washing with soap is just fine.  While it’s a debate inside our household, I err on not using soap when possible and if soap is totally necessary - so be it - at least the company isn’t against the practice!We are sure to put the pan on the stove to dry it completely and then we season the entire pan (all the way to the its rims) with a light coat of oil.  So far so good.  Not everyone in the household is as an*l about caring for the pan so I’m going to be honest, I can see a slight silver of rust showing up.I honestly don’t think any rust would show up if you are very careful of caring for your pan as I’ve described above.  At least at this price, I don’t have to worry about it and it is well worth paying 1/10 the cost of an enameled pan which after reading lots of reviews, they simply don’t make them like they used to make them 30-40 years ago so why bother.The proof in the pudding is if we ended up passing these down to our grandkids or not! :D
title: at 1/10 the cost of enameled pans, it’s worth the spin!

author: Physics Teacher
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2021
review_content: We had forgotten the unsurpassed properties of cast-iron cookware. As most people, we opted exclusively for Teflon, granite, or ceramic coated pans and pots: Not to mislead, we still use them.However, if your looking for high temperature searing and straight into a 450 degree oven, cast iron is the only choice.How we rediscovered cast iron cookware: We bought some 2" bone-in pork chops at Costco. But how to cook without drying them out?We Googled "How to cook thick pork chops" and came across several recipes. The main thing they all had in common was the use of cast iron.Basically, you pre-heat your oven to 425-450 degrees. Meanwhile. put your cast iron skillet on a stove-top burner set on high. Season your olive oil coated chops with Kosher salt (sea salt) and coarse ground pepper. Once the cast iron skillet begins to smoke, sear your chops on both sides (about 2 minutes per side).Immediately transfer the skillet (with chops) into you pre-heated oven. For 2" chops we bake 5 minutes per side.That's all there is to it. Moist and delicious. Since then, we have followed the same process to lamb chops and fish...adjusting time in the oven.PS: If you make spaghetti  sauce from scratch, use a cast iron pot. Why? You end up with a delicious iron enriched sauce.
title: Made in the USA - Pre-seasoned - Solid

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2019
review_content: My first Lodge purchase was a cast iron pot that I loved! It came pre-seasoned and has never given me any issues in the two or three years I've had it. This supposedly came pre-seasoned too. And since getting it a little over a month ago, I've seasoned it myself several times. I don't know why food sticks to it so badly! My pot has never had the issues my skillets have! I have lost so much food to this skillet from it sticking or burning and spent hours scrubbing and re-seasoning. It's infuriating! Apparently quality control has tanked since buying my pot a couple of years ago. I'll be looking into other companies to buy my cast iron from and would recommend future buyers do as well.
title: Quality control has tanked; buy a different brand

author: Lance S. Owens
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2021
review_content: My problem with cast iron was always the sizzling hot handle.  Forget, and touch it, and you are branded and blistered.  Second problem was I never understood how to care for it properly.  So this pan comes with a handle cover that will prevent severe burn.  It still gets darn hot, but you will not be branded.  Second problem solved by just leaving the pan on the stove top.  I wipe out the grease or oil after cooking.  Done.  Occasionally I use a nylon scrub and some hot water on a warm pan, then dry thoroughly and re-oil with a little heat.  Done.  Now it is just part of my stove top -- as was my grandmother's big cast iron pan fifty years ago.  That pan always had a little bacon grease at the bottom....
title: After avoiding cast iron for decades, I love this pan.
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 10.25-InchVerified Purchase

author: Rachel Humphrey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2017
review_content: 😍 Love lodge skillets. This is the standard size (10.5 inch) and depth, great for frying, searing or baking.Cooking and Recipes: Most recipes call for a 10 or 12 inch pan. Definitely use the right size pan with your recipe, it should state what size you need. A 10 inch will hold three chicken breasts, 12 will hold four. Lodge skillets are a little more rough textured than other brands but they still work great and are affordable. I use bamboo utensils on my pans as those are soft enough but not easy to damage. Cast iron skillets work by retaining heat, you can cook on a MUCH lower temperature and attain a more even and quick cook. You also need to match the burner size to the pan size, if your burner is too big for the pan, the pan will not heat properly. You can fry or sear on the stove top and then pop this straight into the oven to bake. It's really a great way to make a one pan meal!Protection : Cast iron IS heavy, I can barely lift it with one hand, which is why this brand makes a helper handle on the opposite side. You need to make sure to use a pot holder for this pan, and leave the potholder ON the handle so that you don't accidently grab it while it is hot. You can make or buy cast iron handle covers that fit perfect. I've made my own :).Cleaning: Take your still warm (but not hot) cast iron and wipe it down with a paper towel to remove debris and oil. Rinse the pan out with warm water, use only a small amount of soap and make sure to wash it all out. You can use a soft sponge or a dish brush. I suggest a brush as sponges like to flake off on the pan's rougher surface. Just be gentle, it doesn't take much to get stuff off and you don't want to damage the surface. Dry the pan off with a towel and place onto a clean burner on medium until it is dry. This prevents rusting.Seasoning: After drying, put 1/2 teaspoon veggie oil in the pan and rub all over inside until it is black and shiny. I use a small tea towel to do this as it won't leave reside, but you can use a paper towel. Just be warned it will probably leave little bits of paper in your pan. You can use tongs to hold your towel if the pan is too hot. Your pan will still be warm, I pop mine into the unheated oven to cool down and stay clean. That's where my little cast iron lives now, in his little oven cave.
title: Happy :)

author: Richdude
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2021
review_content: TL:DR: Great kitchen tool. Will last for years too!So when I was a little kin in the Boy Scouts I still remember going on camping trips and we would have cast iron skillets and dutch ovens. I remember distinctly reading that the cast iron skillet had Lodge on the bottom and one of the troop leaders said that skillet has been with the troop for over 20 years! If you are just getting into cooking with cast iron skillets, its a game changer that's been around for years and years.I'm sticking with the old school style of treating this like many BBQ enthusiasts do: don't wash it! Clean it with water, scour off food and keep it seasoned when not in use. This thing is such a breeze to use, a breeze to clean, and its the best tool in my kitchen next to the wooden spoon. The heat distributes evenly so cooking with all sorts of food will be easy since there are no spots that heat better than others. Also, the surface is nice and roomy so I can fit a lot in it.Lodge will run into a problem eventually because this more or less is a one-time sale. I don't think I will need to buy another one for 20+ years. But I'll be getting them as gifts to my kids so they have a lifetime kitchen tool. Great product!
title: Awesome Skillet!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Binu Balakrishnan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2017
review_content: I had this pan for about two years.  What I had thought was a scratch in the seasoning at the bottom of the pan turned out to be a crack as I began to see oil residue at the bottom.  I don't use this pan often as it's usually overkill for me and my wife, but it was my first CI piece and I was bummed.  I decided to reach out to Lodge and gave them some usage information as well as a few pics.  I was pleasantly surprised that they offered to send me a replacement free of charge!  That is a company that stand behind their product.  As an engineer, I understand that defects happen.  It's how you handle them as a company that makes all the difference.Regarding the product itself, it has worked great besides the crack.  I own 4 Lodge CI pieces, and they have great heat retention for searing and hold up great to metal utensils.  Take care of it by oiling after cleaning and it will just get better with use.
title: Excellent customer service, and a nice product!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: ole 45 mag
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2019
review_content: Upon opening, I did noticed a flaw 1 skillet, like a crack was "rubbed out".  Did everything right on glass top.  Turned heat up a bit but noticed the skillet was cracked with a max opening of 1/8 inch.  Went to look at the other and you could see the crack already.  Both shipped in huge box together.  Went back to kitchen and  once the heated skillet had cooled, crack was 90% gone.  I WOULD MAYBE have noticed the crack in the unheated skillet, but I had purchased over $600 worth of Lodge items,  12 total cooking items, tripod, and handle gloves..all Lodge.  Wanted Lodge for quality.
title: 2-15 inch skillets, 2 cracked.

author: Sheila Harshaw
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2020
review_content: I have been buying pans that are advertised on TV only to be disappointed.  I used to have a cast iron skillet but got rid of it when I bought a glass top stove.  The reason I got this pan was it said can be used on glass top stove  That is true!  I did have to season it again but now nothing sticks I made Schnitzel last night and the coating stay on and didn't stick a bit then this morning I made omelets and they didn't stick!  They came out beautiful and cleanup is wonderful.  I would recommend this pan to everyone.
title: Best Pan Ever!!!!!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 10.25-InchVerified Purchase

author: maisie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2018
review_content: Love it! This is my first cast iron skillet, prior to this I had been using non-stick and stainless steel. Have to admit, I was always intimidated by cast iron because of the care it requires. Realized how wrong I was after cooking with it! I wanted to start making dishes that required stove top to oven cooking and had read that cast iron was perfect for just that. After doing some research, I decided on this one for the quality and affordability. First dish I made, I seared some meat and finished cooking it in the oven. Sidenote: I love how this process only uses one pan -- less to clean! I was initially worried that the meat was going to get stuck to the pan -- but it didn't! Produced the perfect sear that my previous skillets cannot even compete with and the meat turned out delicious! Next, I was concerned that it would be difficult to clean, since there was some bits burned and stuck on the bottom. When this happens in my stainless steel pan I'd have to soak and scrub and scrub...I was amazed when I only had to use a bit of water and some light scrubbing and rinsing to get it up. No soap needed! Took about a minute and the skillet looks just as good as brand new, can't even tell I used it, and it is still well seasoned. Which is another thing I'd like to remark on -- Lodge did a phenomenal job preseasoning! I can't wait to put this to regular use in my kitchen. Also, I used silicone oven mitts when cooking with this and it made it so much easier to transfer the pan, with the grip and the heat resistance. Definitely plan on purchasing more cast iron from this brand.
title: Excellent Quality & Affordability!

author: ron c.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2018
review_content: My mom had cast iron so I got this pan, cooking eggs is a joke. I't say's pre-seasoned but the egg stuck bad so I washed and dried it then Using an olive oil saturated paper towel, coat the entire interior surface liberally, preheat oven to 350 degrees F. Bake the skillet, upside down on the upper rack for 1 hour and next morning tried again and food sticks to it.This pan is no better than one from the 99 cent store.
title: You get what you pay for

author: Cait K
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2018
review_content: Although it claims to come pre-seasoned, it's pretty clear that it isn't enough to keep your food from sticking horribly to the bottom of the pan. I followed a guide online about how to properly season a pan, and I haven't had any issues since. I recommend everyone do that prior to using it. It feels to be pretty standard cast iron, and hopefully lasts a long time, but I was very unimpressed with how rough it was and the lack of proper seasoning.
title: Need to re-season

author: John Gilbert
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2019
review_content: Some people will tell you that it is laborious to have a cast iron skillet.  Not so with the Lodge!  I watched a lot of videos on the youtube about cleaning and care and people were all over the board about removing the factory seasoning and starting over.  No way.  I washed the pan after I received it and the first several times I cooked with it I used some vegetable oil and butter to make sure nothing stuck.  The directions say you can even use soap and water to clean it, so I do.  Then I put it back on the burner for a few minutes to dry as I do the rest of my dishes and Then I rub some vegetable Crisco all over it and then wipe it down real good and put it away for the day.  So maybe 1 extra step in the cleanup process.  I have cooked eggs and meats and so far I have had nothing stick.
title: Easy to live with.
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2020
review_content: I usually don’t write reviews but this is one of the best purchases I have ever made. I always have been apprehensive about non stick pans with coating as it eventually will peel off and it may cause cancer. So I went ahead and purchased my first cast iron. I’m completely in love with this baby. I was worried about it would stick before using it, due to its rough surface, but once I season it properly in the oven and preheat it on the stove for like a minute before cooking, it is 100% non stick. I have no trouble frying eggs. And the flavor of food definitely taste different than regular non stick pan, it adds this grilled flavor to my food. For care, I always burn the water off, it after washing it so never had any rust issues at all. It is also easy to clean after soaking it for about 10 mins. I’m overall very happy with this pan and it will no doubt last for a lifetime.
title: Buy this pan
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 10.25-InchVerified Purchase

author: Jenn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2019
review_content: This skillet is great. It is sturdy and seems to heat evenly. I bought it because I wanted a pan that could easily transition from stove to oven or vis versa and could get a nice sear on meat.A lot of reviewers complained about rust, but that can easily be avoided with the proper care. First is to ensure you clean it quickly. I usually let mine cool down significantly, add some water and let it sit a minute before washing. Second is to not let it air dry. As soon as it has been washed, dry it with a towel! This is the biggest factor in getting rust. Once dried, rub it down with oil and either put in the oven or on the stove until the oil has begun dissipating. This will ensure the pan does not get sticky from excess oil. Follow these and your pan will last you a dozen life times.The biggest con of the skillet is how heavy it is. I can barely lift it with one hand... Just requires me to be extra careful.
title: Great Skillet
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: N
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2021
review_content: The bottom isn't flat. Not really an for issue gas stoves or electric stoves with the coil. I've used (flat bottmed) cast iron on my glass top stove for a long time, I've never had a problem with a pan not being flat until this thing.I returned the first one which was very not flat and then I got the second one which is slightly not flat. This makes it so heat transfer is really uneven.I did a ton of extra seasoning on it and it seemed to help some, but I'm still going to take sandpaper to it to smooth the high spot.
title: If you have a glass top stove maybe consider something else

author: Andy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2021
review_content: If you haven’t seared steaks on a cast iron pan with butter, then baked them in an oven (Ruth’s Chris style), then you really haven’t had steak. Buy yourself this pan and stop reading reviews on Amazon!They’re affordable pans that are super versatile and will last you a lifetime or two!
title: Steaks + cast iron = match made in heaven!

author: J. Driscoll
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2020
review_content: As a disclaimer, I was a big fan of Lodge pans, and I guess if you're looking for a entry level cast iron pan to go with, they're still going to be the best value. That said, I just ordered their 8" pan, which came with a small hole on the cooking surface. I ordered a replacement to be sent by Amazon, and that one came with a similar sized hole on inside wall (see pics). I have three other Lodge pans of different sizes, and I've never before seen these defects in their pans, and now I've seen it twice in a row.I've just decided to keep the replacement pan and try to sand down the small hole on the inner wall surface so that it doesn't trap moisture in it and start to rust over time, and that is why it looks shiny around the hole.In the future, I think I'm going to start splurging for the iron pans that have a real machine finish to them.
title: Lodge quality going down

author: GMK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2019
review_content: I love this cast iron.  I always used non-stick pans that I knew wasn't good for me for sake of ease of use.  But doing more and more research, I found cast iron to be something I wanted to experiment with.  Problem with cast iron is there is so many conflicting information out there.  So I found on SeriousEats.com some guides and some videos by Cowboy Kent Rollins on YouTube.  Very instructive and simple to follow.  I highly recommend to read through the website and watch the videos if you are new to cast iron cookware.  I know many will polish or sand down the Lodge prior to re-seasoning for smooth cooking surface but I did not.  I did do initial re-seasoning in the oven with crisco and I just been using it everyday.  I've owned this for little over a week and now, I can cook eggs on it without sticking.  It's not completely non-stick like teflon but pretty darn close.  The rough texture is starting to smooth out since I take time to add to the seasoning on stovetop after every use.  Take 10 minutes tops for me.  Heat it up using med-medium  high heat until dry, rub some crisco on it in thin layers, wipe it off with lint free rag and wait until it starts to look dry on the bottom then take it off the heat to cool.  Finished!  I love my Lodge cast iron.  I'm hoping to one day hand it down to my daughter.
title: My first cast iron

author: Donna Kine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2014
review_content: UPDATE: 8/5/2017:  This pan and I have been on a bit of a journey.  Years ago, I relegated this skillet to storage because it was a bit overwhelming in my micro-kitchen with 'doll house'-size stove.  Anyway, moved to a new place with normal kitchen and rediscovered the skillet hiding in the back of the pantry.  I hadn't used it in about a year, and the cooking surface was completely covered with rust.  I asked the skillet for forgiveness, and my penance was a good long while of sandpaper-ing that rust out.  Once the rust was gone, I re-seasoned several times by wiping lightly with oil and baking in a 450 degree oven for about 30 minutes each cycle.  Came out looking like new!But now came the test - how would she cook?  I've picked up some more cooking wisdom over the years, and changed my pan frying skills a bit.  This seems to do the trick: preheat on MEDIUM-LOW to LOW heat with a teaspoon of oil, and it's ready to cook just about anything.  The skillet and I have finally come to an understanding, and the cooking surface is as slick as teflon.  Even cheesy scrambled eggs slide right out. After each time I use it, I wipe it out with paper towel/scraper/salt, maybe give it gentle clean with barely soapy water on cooking surface (yes, I'm in that camp), and towel dry thoroughly.  Then I put it back on burner over HIGH heat, and add another teaspoon of oil which I rub around the cooking surface with a wadded-up paper towel.  I leave the heat on until the oil in the pan BARELY starts to smoke, then shut off the heat and give the pan one more wipe with the clean side of that wadded-up paper towel.  Leaves the skillet looking show-room beautiful and ready for the next meal.Original Post:  I was so excited to get my first cast iron pan!  I've been trying to care for it exactly as the Lodge website (and most of these comments) suggests.The silicone handle is great - doesn't get too hot, and slides on and off easily.I've been cooking a lot of bacon in the pan to help with the seasoning, but sticking is still a bit of an issue (tried some hashbrowns the other day...didn't work so well).  I've also noticed that the bottom doesn't quite heat evenly, even after "preheating" before placing food on the pan.  I only use the pan on our largest burner, and it covers most of the pan bottom, but there is still a hot spot in the center third of the pan.I'll attribute the current issues to this being a new pan in need of more TLC before I make my final judgement.  So far I do enjoy cooking on the pan and feel very homey using cast iron in the kitchen!
title: Wonderful skillet that somehow survived my neglect!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Jean Bates
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2018
review_content: Absolutely love this pan! I have a glass top stove so was hesitant on purchasing this pan. You will need a pot holder or a silicone handle because this pan retains heat but overall, this is the best pan in the house. I don't have to worry about high heat and sticking! I did some seasoning after cooking by rinsing and cleaning the pan with water, setting pan on eye of stove at high heat until smoke appeared, pouring oil into pan and wiping with paper towel and again waiting for the high heat to smoke the oil. (There are many ways to get that shiny seasoned surface)  Nothing sticks hard on this pan and is easy to scrape even after cooking eggs! I want to purchase the bigger pans but don't want to risk breaking the glass on my stove. Easy to clean, no scrubbing and no burning pans on high heat. What more can you ask for?
title: The Best Pan I Own!

author: MissEbony94513
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2019
review_content: I had to replace my wonderful cast iron skillet I had been using for about 15 years; I dropped it and it broke. I bought this one by Lodge and overall it's "ok" but it is not ideal. The skillet surface is rough and no matter what I do food sticks to it very badly and is quick to burn. Forget about scrambling eggs or frying something because it always, always sticks! I suppose I will be returning this and buying something that I can see before I actually purchase. The surface needs to be smooth and I am not sure if that is something that happens over time or if it should be smooth to begin with. I don't recall with my old Skillet unfortunately, because it was handed down to me by my mom and it was given to my mom by my grandmother. I'm disappointed.
title: Food sticks and the skillet rusts easily!!!

author: Jim@ipswichtownvillas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2018
review_content: Most cast iron skillets will do a great job once they are seasoned.  This pan is pre-seasoned and a quick wipe and spritz with oil was all I needed to fry a quick batch of bacon.  Wiped it with a paper towel to make it ready for cornbread.  The handle is just the right size to allow the entire pan to fit in my countertop oven.  This skillet does not come with a cover, I purchased one separately from Lodge (Amazon) and it fit perfectly, turning this skillet into a Dutch oven.  I really like the Buffalo Nickle design on the bottom.
title: Great for steaks, burgers, buns and cornbread

author: Shirtless Cubs Fan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2016
review_content: I'm not sure what purpose others find with a skillet so small, but I bought this as a gift for my daughter who loves cooking on my CI.  The reason I went so small is because we already have several skillets of various sizes and she loves making eggs.  This is perfect for sausage, egg, and bacon biscuits or for a single sunny-side up egg for an English muffin.As usual with other Lodge products, there is a pre-season, but I wash all my new Lodge with hot, soapy water, and then I grind/sand down the cooking surface to achieve a smooth texture, as the casting method Lodge uses leaves a rough, orange peel texture that's quite unpleasant for me when scraping with certain utensils.  This texture will eventually smooth in over time and use, but I actually enjoy my method and applying my own base seasoning down.
title: Perfect For Cooking Single Eggs!

author: stephenb
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2018
review_content: I already love cooking in cast iron. But this is better than I expected. I had read on various forums that the current Lodge cast iron cookware is rough and not as smooth as vintage cast iron because the insides are not machined. And that's true. Even so, I finally purchased this because I needed a large skillet for cooking for larger numbers of people. I discovered that the slightly rougher cook service cooked just as well as the smooth vintage cast iron I had previously used, at least for the sorts of foods I was making (mostly meats and saags so far). The skillet I received came pre-seasoned and made in USA as advertised. I'm only about a month into cooking with it, but so far, the seasoning is holding up nicely.Also, as far as I can tell, this is the largest size cast iron skillet that Lodge makes a matching cast iron lid for.
title: I already love cooking in cast iron. But this is better than I expected

author: Tweet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2020
review_content: When you need a BIG cast iron pan, this is it. This falls in the be careful what you wish for category, like 12” chef knives. It’s heavy, and big, so washing it by hand in the sink you need to take care not to dent the steel or chip the countertop. It’s not going to play nice in a jumble of other pots and pans in that hard to reach occasional use cabinet. But it does what only a cast iron pan can do. Also makes a passable cat bed.
title: Heavy metal for crowd cooking

author: Charles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2021
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.                       With all the varying takes in the reviews, I wasn't sure what exactly I'd get. But here's what played out for me:I bought the skillet to sear some ribeyes on my gas stove top. It did come "preseasoned" (which really means pre-oiled, i.e. the metal has been conditioned with canola oil before it was shipped). I used a high smoke point olive oil, butter, and I rendered plenty of the fat from the steaks while searing. They came out great! I've always been told never wash your cast iron with soap as it strips the metal of its seasoning, so I've only rinsed it with hot water and wiped it out with a paper towel. I've used it to make scrambled eggs, bacon, and toast among other staples and I'm happy to report that I've never had a problem with anything sticking to the skillet. (By the way, ignore the video of the lady and her guy who posted the clip of her cooking eggs. She clearly didn't know how to make proper scrambled eggs and burned them and MADE them stick to the skillet. If you pop in a little oil and butter and let the skillet heat up, you should have no issues with this simple dish.) Now that I've built up some actual seasoning in it, I'm going to do a simple bacon risotto next.This has been such an incredible tool in my kitchen since I've gotten it. Well worth the buy! If you're considering it, just do it! This same model is in Walmart, and I think this is actually cheaper than what you'd spend in store. You can't go wrong with this!
title: I LOVE MY IRON

author: Charles Laquidara
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2020
review_content: I only expected a cast iron pan nothing special, but once I picked this thing up and saw the way it was constructed, the way it felt to hold (very heavy, by the way - but that's a good thing!) . I followed the instructions, oiled it up, put it in the oven, turned off the oven -- and the next day I had a beautiful work of culinary art. I love the way this pan feels and the way it cooks (evenly). It gets hot quickly and I have since put away my favorite non-stick pan - as this will now be my everyday cooking pan!
title: This is the Pan of all Pans
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Ronald R
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2020
review_content: This is my first cast iron experience and I wasn't really sure what to expect from Lodge with their rough finish on the skillet. So many mixed reviews with many recommending grinding to smooth the inside surface. I decided to see for myself and I'm glad I did. After 3x additional seasoning with canola oil in my oven, the pan was given it's first use with great success. Since then I've cooked several other dishes and have had no sticking (better than my no stick pan) and minimal cleanup. You must follow some basic techniques which are easy to find on YouTube but don't file anything smooth because it works great as is.I'd like to add that this 9" pan has no 2nd handle and makes it into my larger sized toaster oven, where it's been going routinely for the baking part of recipes.
title: Great Product

author: sidney hoyle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2019
review_content: cast iron will never go out of style, the hear retention in cast iron is amazing and the searing and browning is to perfection and with the larger 12'' surface area for certain types of cooking it unbeatable, but here's one warning about this pan... this is a 12'' cast iron pan... its VERY heavy... You go into it knowing that... so if you want to use this pan to pick up and pour things out of it can be challenging because of the size and weigh. It dose have a helper handle on the opposite end of the pan but if you need a free hand to scrape or push out what ever you have in the pan then you may need the help of another person. And being that its iron you don't want to wash it with soap and you should oil it after every use to keep the seasoning. I usually spritz the pan with some natural non-stick cooking spray or coconut oil, wipe the excess with a paper towel and store it in the oven, but like I initially said, this is cast iron so you go into it understanding certain things the for lifting and pouring in particular you may want to use another pan for that meal
title: what can i say, its cast iron whats not to love...
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: JJM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2018
review_content: With four growing children i needed a bigger cast Iron skillet for weekend breakfast cooking and wasnt disappointed with this. I debated the 17” lodge pan, but this 15” is really more than enough and I don’t think most people will need something bigger. I wanted the skillet handle and this one has it vs the 17”. Pan is heavy, as you would expect. i wish a cast iron lid was available, but they only have glass. I bought the 13.25” lodge skillet which has a cast iron lid and for many things it works better then the 15”. But for a big batch of potatoes etc the 15” delivers. I gave it four stars vs 5 as the surface of the Lodge skillets are a bit rough, and I end up using my grinder to strip the factory finish and polish it very smooth: You dont have to, but it would be nice for another $ or 2 if lodge had a slighly smoother cooking surface for the skillets. on the 15” pan the surface had a few air pin holes in the surface once ground down, again no big deal, a a slightly better cooking surface finish is a plus. This pan, like all my lodge cast iron will last several life times. i have grown to prefer them over teflon coated Calphanon etc...
title: Big pan, if you are thinking 15 vs 17, get this one.

author: Flannel Pajamas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2018
review_content: My go-to pan for 90 percent of my cooking. Food tastes better. For the money, quality, and best of all food flavor...I would be hard pressed to go back to my expensive stainless steel pan. Don't believe the hype about expensive pans. This is a pan that has stood the test of time. It sears, sautes, stir frys, and cooks eggs without sticking. Easy to learn, and easy to make my food taste great. I use the same pan without cleaning it all day. Then when I am done for the day, I wash in hot water with a strong brush. Don't use soap, always dry on the stove and season with oil. Do not leave this pan wet, EVER. It can ruin it instantly. That's right, I only wash this pan once a day after I am done cooking a full day's worth of meals.  Can't do that with an expensive stainless steel pan.
title: Best Pan in My Kitchen
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Ash
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2020
review_content: I have been using Lodge 10" griddle for many years and loved cooking pancakes, quesadillas, roti and parathas on my coil stove. I always believed that if I invest in cast iron skillets and pans, they would not befriend my stir fry meals like fried rice, pasta, potatoes and eggs will be the biggest enemy! I saw many youtube videos and then thought to try this small size with such low price. In beginning I was not giving enough time to warm up this pan and that's why eggs would always stick to this skillet. Then I learnt that these cast iron can take over 5 mins to get heated enough. When I gave that much time eggs and potatoes just slid of the pan and didn't stick a bit. The heating is so even that all food in pan gets cooked uniformly. This is life changer for me as I am definitely going to get 12" skillet as I make mostly stir fry meals. I guess this is the last 8" frying pan I am ever going to buy. I had been sick and tired of buying and tossing away all those nonstick pans as they don't last more than a couple of years. Even hard anodized ones. Long live Lodge pans!!
title: Lodge Family will keep growing!!

author: chrisT
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2020
review_content: Aside from two small 1/4" areas of finish (pictured) on the edge which I was unsure if just color difference or finish potential problem, these are great. Those spots haven't caused any issues.Cast iron pans really are not for people who tend to set dirty pans in the sink over night full of water. Don't do that then complain about the pan developing rust. They are iron + sit in water = eventually develop rust.I don't use it for everything, though I could, because sometimes I prefer to set a dirty pan in the sink full of water overnight.I use it mostly for searing, and for baking cornbread and getting that amazing crispiness on the bottom crust.This pan has been easy and non-stick having been pre-seasoned. Just wash and dry after using, add a quick and thin coat of vegetable oil, and it's ready to go for next time. I usually put on burner after towel drying to heat it just a moment, then add the oil to still warm pan, and spread with a bit of paper towel.  That's how my mom used to do it, and it works great for me keeping the pans fresh, well dried, and non-stick.Very happy with this pan, and the price was surprisingly good... Cast iron pans will last a lifetime... or more.
title: great pre-seasoned non-stick, good value

author: Chris R
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
review_content: bought in 2013 and we use it daily.  replaced some allclad non stick where the surface was flaking off.  this thing has gotten better with age.  Bacon, steak searing, chili on the BGE, fried chicken.. the list is endless.  when we purchased it the surface was pebbled.  it soon filled with carbon goodness and is mirror smooth.We do use pam cooking spray to prep the pan, and that certainly helps with non stick.  we have the 12 inch and added an 8 inch to our arsenal.  I bought a grinder and smoothed out the pebbles on the 8 inch.  Turns out it hurt the non stick capabilities of the pan.  leave it factory fresh and use it often!  one day my kids will own it, but for now, its mine.
title: i'm on year 7...

author: The Outdoor Dad
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2021
review_content: It’s a small cast iron skillet. I knew it was small because it states it’s size in the description.Problem is, it’s smaller than the listed size.I don’t think the cooking surface inside the skillet bottom is even 6” because the sides widen as it get to the top of the skillet, and it’s just over 6” in diameter at the rim.When you’re dealing with that small of a size, a discrepancy of half an inch is a lot. It’s good enough for one small meal, which I can use when hunting. However, I bought this for our travel trailer, so I’ll be cooking for at least 2.Will be looking for a slightly bigger (and more true to stated size) cast iron skillet now. Will also likely be a Lodge skillet, since their skillets are the best, even if they’re not as big as they advertise.
title: It’s not 6.5” in diameter. It’s barely 6”.

author: Jack Barns
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2021
review_content: This is an amazing deal especially if your willing to put some elbow grease in. The pan comes pre-seasoned, but I wanted my pan smooth as glass. I ordered 240 grit sandpaper on Amazon for $3. I left my pan on the counter and I would sand the bottom of the pan 10min here.....5min there. I just did it little by little when I had time. After 3 days of doing this off and on my pan is as smooth as glass. It's literally a night and day difference with minimum work. I didn't sand the whole pan just the bottom. Now I will re-season it and it will be as non-stick as teflon, but without the danger.  240 grit sandpaper is extra fine and will remove those big pours and lumps on your pan.  Also you cant go wrong with LODGE....its real cast iron made in America.
title: GREAT FIND

author: Sailor Bill
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2019
review_content: A plastic Lodge scraper and a stainless scrub pad is all you need to keep it clean. Never use soap. I just restored my older pans that were in storage for 3 years, and bit rusty, with the SS scrub pad, and then baked them in the oven per Lodge's instructions, except  I used coconut oil instead of olive. They looked pretty much perfect after a quick scrub - again, no soap - but I did the baking thing anyway. Some food sticks a bit, but is so easily cleaned off. Did is mention to never use soap?Heating is very even, except with the square pancake pan where the corners don't get hot enough to evenly cook your pancakes. I use the larger fry pan for pancakes now. If you want to save a little gas or electricity, turn the burner off about a minute or 2 before your food is done. There is so much residual heat in these heavy pans that food will finish cooking.Unlike "non-stick" cookware, you will never need to baby these. And, ladies, given how heavy and indestructible they are, they may prove useful for getting hubby's and teenager's undivided attention.
title: Cast iron is the best!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 8-InchVerified Purchase

author: Consumer Kaizencraft
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2018
review_content: This isn't a skillet or a kitchen tool or some domestic appliance. You're literally buying five founds of solid iron in a particular shape - no wood, plastic, detachable pieces, moving parts, etc. What you do with it is only limited to your creativity and means but of course a specifically awesome thing is to put meat and vegetables in it and heat it up. But again, it's very simply only metal and so the only requirement is for it to be hot which is not very difficult. Blowtorch, car engine, camp fire, the heat of the sun, things with a 'DANGER - EXTREME HEAT' sign, cigarette lighters in concert. There's something great about the simplicity of wielding two solid basic elements to transform a simple piece of meat into something so enticing and delicious. I don't want to overromanticize and rant like a foolish hipster, but it's almost empowering not to be condescended to by some robot or disenfranchised human. It's empowering even - everyone who cooks for you who aren't your friends or family aren't serving you as a person, of course. Your personality and satisfaction are metrics with numbers they'll find ways to change however they can within the limits of consumers' current standards of appropriate and "not horrible", even the small holes-in-the-wall (minus the powerpoint).And there's no magic to it. Nothing to break, fix, upgrade, add to, decorate, or even throw away. I'll list 5 random things that come to mind: a rake, a lawnmower, a clock, an old vinyl record, beauty lotion. How well do any of those fair in extreme temperatures? Could they shield you from an arrow? How about a bullet? How about four bullets? Nine? If you hit Mike Tyson with any of those objects, would he still be able to get up and absolutely murder you? How well would any of them protect you from a ray/beam of high intensity light? What would happen if they were thrown onto the rocky shores of a towering cliff? And could any of them be worn as makeshift armor in the event of a home invasion? Of course some of these things are far fetched but there's still merit in the utility of one single piece of heavy iron, and I'm not saying anything Tyler Durden already hasn't taught an entire generation but my thing is, if a duvet is just a blanket, seriously check out all the things a blanket can do. They are fabric swiss army knives.
title: Calling it a "skillet" undersells the genius of its utility and its ability to be productive even during a structure fire

author: Sammy Pie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2020
review_content: I have a collection of Lodge skillets and dutch ovens. They are all the same, and they are great. With one caveat: they are great for cast iron lovers. If you are not into cast iron, you can get modern designed pans/skillets with better actual features.Pros and cons below can be applied to any Lodge cast iron product.Cons:Needs constant seasoning, and lots of care. Otherwise it will rust, and/or your food will stick.If you are not used to cast iron cooking, be careful with the temperatures: cast iron retains heat much longer than a regular pan.The "pre-seasoned" feature is overrated. The item arrives to you with a layer of some artificial seasoning. The only purpose of it is to make sure the pan gets from factory to store without developing rust. It doesn't help cooking, food will still stick to the factory seasoning.Pros:If you are grilling on open fire and high heat, I know of nothing that can beat cast iron.If you are not into [lovingly] wasting more time on caring for you pan than cooking in it, get yourself a modern pan (either non stick aluminum/steel of enameled cast iron).
title: Cast iron, what can you say...

author: Joe Bush
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2020
review_content: I bought the 13.25" skillet to complement the 20" Lodge griddle we've had (and loved) for over a decade. As expected, the skillet is solid, heavy, and BIG. Carefully measure your cooking space (stove burners, outdoor grill, etc...) before purchasing this skillet to ensure it's a good fit. Additionally, make sure the skillet can fit in your sink to be washed. It may seem silly to stress this point but I forgot to measure my sink and lucked out in that the skillet fits, but with only an inch to spare! So far I love this versatile skillet and reach for it at every opportunity. It is roomy enough to put a great sear on a large roast, the sides are tall enough to deep fry chicken, you can make gravy, beautifully caramelize onions, whip up a party-sized batch of cornbread, and the list goes on. I've had absolutely no problem cleaning the skillet. Let it cool completely so that it's safe to handle, pour any remaining oil into an appropriate container, and use a pan scraper to remove as much residue as possible. To avoid damaging your sink, especially if it's enamel, line it with kitchen towels and then transfer the skillet to it. Fill the skillet with very hot water and let rest for a few minutes to soften stuck-on food before using a scraper or non-abrasive scrub brush. Pour out the water and repeat the process as necessary. Give a final rinse and  thoroughly dry with a lint-free cloth. Moisten a paper towel with some cooking oil and apply a light coating to the skillet before storing it in a dry location. I can' t say enough good things about this skillet and the many tasty meals it's produced.
title: This family-sized skillet is a winner!

author: Patmn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2021
review_content: I ordered one of these pans about a month ago and loved it so much that I ordered another right away.  It’s fun to make chocolate chip cookies, frittatas, and many other great dishes, and each person gets their own very adorable skillet.  I ordered two more of these pans and had to return them because of defects in both pans.  One had a piece missing around the edge, and the other had defects in the finish.  I thought maybe because they were shipping in the same box with no padding that they scraped into each other.  I ordered two more in separate orders and they were both defective as well. One had a gouge in the bottom of the skillet and the other had defects in the finish in many places.  These were shipped together in the same box, too, even though they were ordered in different orders at different times, which was surprising.  I don’t know if cast iron pans can be damaged by clanging together in a box.  Since it’s such a heavy material, I feel the pans should have been ok.  It’s almost like I got “seconds”, or “outlet” pans.  They may be fine to use, but I would want to know ahead of time if I’m not getting perfect condition.  I’m going to try again.  I just ordered one pan.  I’m going to wait two days and then order another pan.  My advice for Amazon: Please check items for damage before they are shipped!  If these pans are also defective, then I give up.  Even though Amazon makes it easy to return, I don’t want to spend any more time running to UPS with my returns!
title: Love the two good pans I received.  Had to return four other detective pans.

author: Scottomus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2021
review_content: Like others have noted, the 13.25" skillet arrived with the handle poking out of the box with minimal internal packing.  Open the box and the size will impress you - I initially thought, what did I do?!!  After multiple uses, I am glad its big.  Its nice to sear 4 large chops with room to spare, then deglaze & place right into the oven.  Its not too big for the electric burner and keeps even temperature. The walls and larger area helps minimize splatter.  Pre-seasoning, is just that, its OK but seasoning is an ongoing process. Use it and it will continue to improve.  I didn't measure my sink in advance, and it doesn't fit down inside, but that's  ok.  I wash it mostly horizontally, resting on the edges of the sink. It is big and heavy, so plan on two hands to move it. When you think about it, it travels to the stove top, oven and sink, pretty much exclusively. Not a lot of transit really, so its size and weight are very manageable. Just no pancake flipping in the air with this one!  :)  I call her "Moh-Reta" and she lives in the pan drawer below the oven with "Gigantor", my 9Qt DO (whos lid fits this skillet perfectly!)  The 9Q DO is huge too, but is perfect for large roasts and bread, with about the same footprint as the 7QT, just more capacity. I am happy with this size, but may look at a 12" skillet for diversity, just as I am eyeing the 5QT DO :)
title: 13.25 - is big, but very manageable

author: Cats Lives Matter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
review_content: Oh my gosh...this skillet is brilliant! It comes pre-seasoned (but you do have to clean & season before next use) and with clear instructions.I always heard how great using a cast iron skillet was, but I didn't have one. I decided on Lodge for the name & reputation but the sale price didn't hurt also.Cooks evenly and can be put in oven for a lovely-cooked steak!Word of advice - DO get the handle protector!! It's shaped perfectly and protects your hand from when it gets hot. Better then using a pot holder!
title: FABULOUS!!

author: CMR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review_content: I'm not fond of cast iron because of the weight but I love how it cooks certain foods. Cooks steak better than BBQing it. Can sear a steak and get that outer crust and it cooks it medium rare perfectly. Pretty easy clean up too. Scrape excess residue with a metal spatula and once cool I wash in hot soapy water, rinse and immediately dry thoroughly.  Then give a light coat of oil on the inside and lay a paper towel over it and store.
title: Good cast iron skillet

author: A. Mullen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2020
review_content: Great skillet.  Reminds me of the behemoth skillets my grandmother used (and later my mom) with one exception.  Those old skillets were smooth on the interior, not pitted like the Lodge's.  I guess Lodge's manufacturing engineers can't be bothered to set up an interior finishing station that would sand these out in about 30 seconds.  Pity.They do work however, and work well.  They're also easy to clean and season.  They just need to be smoother on the inside.
title: Just a little bit finer grind on the interior and it would be five stars...
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Uncle Michael
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
review_content: The first thing that I would recommend doing with this cast-iron skillet is to remove the pre-seasoning and re-season this skillet at least 3 to 4 times before using. Once you have a proper seasoning on this skillet it is unstoppable. I have cooked so many different dishes inside of this cast-iron skillet including desserts. If you take care of this skillet, Meaning you cook with it, you clean it properly (no dish soap, not even a little), and re-season it after every use, it will last you a lifetime and produce some of the best food you have ever eaten.
title: Cast my stomach in iron.

author: Dan Guinn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2019
review_content: BACK STORY: For many hikers, who enjoy cooking in the outdoors there is a general pain with the stainless steel mess kits, I went through the same. It's almost impossible not to burn the pan as it doesn't distribute heat well enough. There is a trick you can do with oil to prep them that works well, but it of course takes more time and the underside of the pan will still burn and have to be cleaned. I switched to the anodized, which works better in comparison with no prep needed. However, the cast iron is a step beyond. It heats just as you would expect and is a great even cook and takes less heat to get results. The only minimal challenges are:1) you need a pot holder or sleeve for the handle, it gets real hot.2) you need a pot holder square glove to store it if you plan to hike after, as it will still be hot.3) the weight, but the 3.5 inch is quite lite and if you have ultra-light gear already, this is not much of an impact.These three things are fine with me for the cooking results. Thus far, I've test cooked drop-biscuits, eggs, cookies and fish cakes, all with amazing results (see pictures). I'm cooking with isobutane on an MSR pocket rocket. We are becoming fast-friends and I will be eating well on the trail for years to come! I just love it! Thank you Lodge for a great product!
title: Lodge 3.5 Inch Cast Iron Mini Skillet

author: Lapis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2020
review_content: It can not be overstated how WONDERFUL THIS PAN IS, and I love that it has been made in the U.S. for over 100 years. Especially right now, that means a lot to me. After extensive research and watching the stellar review of this pan on America's Test Kitchen, I decided to give it a try. WOW! Heat distribution, excellent. Problems with food sticking, very few. Weight, HEFTY! Just make sure you READ ALL OF THE INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE you use the pan for the first time. VERY IMPORTANT!! I almost washed the pan with soap and water before I tried it out & would have ruined the seasoned finish (factory seasoned finish means you don't have to go through that long, pain in the ass process yourself). Just follow the care instructions for use and clean up and you will probably be just as pleased as I have been with this pan. It may be more expensive than other cast iron skillets, but it will probably be the last one you have to buy. And just remember, you're supporting an American company who are hiring American workers. What more could you want right now?
title: The BEST option for a Lodge skillet & the matching silicone grip!!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Moo!!!
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2017
review_content: I haven't used non-enameled cast iron since my later childhood years.  I always had some good memories with Lodge...grandma's pancakes, a hearty stew cooking in a Ben Franklin wood burning stove and so on...  I love my Le Creuset (the only enameled cast iron I'll buy), but I have been wanting to bring back some old family recipes, prepared in their traditional way...with Lodge...still made in the USA...I had to get some pieces.I've always hated nonstick, Teflon coated and the like cookware.  I even tried enamel over metal pans...they work ok, but I like cooking with fats and oils...and that tends to make the enameled layer not so nonstick and the flavors just aren't right.  So, back to Lodge...I almost forgot how inexpensive and easy these are to care for.  I  started with this 10.25" skillet.  It was easy to clean with mild soap before use.  I did a quick seasoning (although it is pre-seasoned well) with an organic cast iron oil...super easy!My first "dish" made in this was a custardy French toast for my daughter and I.  The heat was easy to attain, and our French toast cooked evenly and to perfection.  --Absolutely no sticking.  I seriously wasn't expecting nonstick effect upon first use!!!  The butter and coconut oil I used melted beautifully...no scorching and the oils were evenly distributed in the dish, while cooking.  I was also able to use stainless steel utensils without fear.  I've always made a good French toast, but this batch was my best yet.  The egg mixture that overflowed and surrounded the toast was delicate and fluffy (as it should be)...not the hardened crispy fried egg effect (gross).The most beautiful part of our experience with this Lodge fry pan....clean up...everything wiped out with just a simple paper towel, mild soap and water wash, then quick seasoning on the stove, wipe out excess, put away.  This seriously is the best no frills, no stress, "no need to sacrifice or skimp on flavor" and "healthy for you" nonstick cookware...and it's just about as inexpensive as the throw away, unhealthy nonstick cookware at your local discount store.What I love about Lodge cast iron...it can be put on a campfire, grill, wood burning stove or firepit and still keep it's appearance with simple care (no worries over pretty enamel getting ugly or metals losing it's shine or luster) and STILL be able to use it on the stove or in the oven...no warping.  It's an inexpensive investment that I'll be able to pass down; along with my more expensive investments like Le Creuset, All Clad and Mauviel.  I also love that Lodge cast iron is made in Tennessee, USA.  (*their enameled items are made in China)  It's not "beautiful", but I love incorporating it's rawness with the beautiful...nice balance in a functional kitchen.I also purchased the 5qt Lodge Dutch Oven   Lodge L8DO3 Cast Iron Dutch Oven, Pre-Seasoned, 5-Quart          .  --The lid fits my 10.25" fry pan perfectly, and I don't need to spend $20+ for a special fitting lid.  Cast iron may not be expensive, but I still enjoy saving money and having less clutter (of unnecessary pieces).
title: Highly recommended for healthy nonstick cookware

author: Brit
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2019
review_content: My only regret was not purchasing sooner.  Quickly became a kitchen staple for me. My boyfriend says I made the best steak and salmon he's ever had in this. He even says my salmon is better than Devon's Seafood & Steak! My favorite thing to cook is my thick ribeye steak drizzled with whiskey and finishing butter, with a blend of mushrooms, vidalia onion, and garlic cooked in the same skillet. So incredible.I took note from other reviewers regarding the seasoning. I seasoned this again myself using olive oil and baking in the oven for an hour. I had no issues at all with food sticking. These are so easy to clean. I will take the skillet to water and wash it off while the pan is hot. If the skillet has cooled, I boil water in it to clean it.
