Once dried with paper towel, I drizzle a little olive oil while the skillet is still warm and wipe it over with the paper towel. I find this much easier to clean than any of my other pans.Subsequently, I use this to cook as much as I can in. You cant beat the flavor and texture cast iron imparts on food. In the short time I have had this, I have made steak, salmon, pork chops, spaghetti sauce, beer tacos, and I'm sure the list will continue to grow.
title: Amazing!!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: jj.kayak
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2020
review_content: The ad has changed, as at the time I ordered, I thought I was getting the logo with the deer head on the bottom of the pan.  This has not been used yet as bought as a Christmas gift that was planned to hang on the chimney above our wood stove (based on deer head on the bottom that was showing at the time I purchased) when not in use.  ( I can't really complain about that since it was such a good price AND Made in USA.)  Further, not sure about the pebbled surface on the bottom--not smooth.  (Can't rate the other features--e.g. heat distribution, ease of cleaning, or heat resistance--as have not used yet.  I gave 3* as appears to be an average pan and because of pebbled bottom cooking surface and not getting what the ad had shown at the time of purchase.
title: Bottom is pebbled, not smooth

author: JWS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
review_content: I have become tired of "non-stick" skillets that deteriorate over time. So I decided to go back to the best non-stick surface of all: cast iron.Lodge makes great cast iron skillets, and they are made in the USA. The brand is always at the top of the list of recommended cast iron. It comes "pre-seasoned," but Lodge recommends washing it and seasoning it by rubbing in a small amount of oil (canola etc.). I used it the next day, and it perfectly cooked a fried egg with limited sticking (cast iron gets more stick-free the more you use it). I was able to flip the egg without any problem (and with a metal turner/spatula!). And it should get even better over time.Cleaning was easy. I used hot water and a little soap (no, soap doesn't 'remove' the seasoning--seasoning polymerizes the oil and it adheres to the surface). Lodge says you can use soap if you want with no harm. Then I completely dried it off (cast iron will rust!) and reseasoned it (it's always a good idea).I used cast iron decades ago, but for some reason stopped--not because of any problems. I always enjoyed the non-stick qualities, rugged durability, and easy cleaning.Keep in mind, these cast-iron pans are HEAVY. If you're used to stainless steel or aluminum, you're in for a change! But it's worth it.I liked this one so much, that I bought a 10.5" one! Highly recommended!
title: Great US-made small skillet. "Non-stick" from day one! Highly recommended!

author: John Hopkins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2018
review_content: Great product. I almost did not buy it because I thought it too was small to be usefel. I bought it along with the Lodge 2-Quart Serving Pot because the same lid fits both. I have been pleasantly surprised. I have used it often. After careful seasoning after receiving it has become my go to pan for sunny side up eggs for 1 or 2. I heat it slowly while I cook my breakfast potatoes in my 12 inch Lodge. Spray liberally with cooking spray and put in 2 to 4 eggs and cover. A few minutes later over a low heat you have 2-4 perfect eggs. I often do omelets in it!This 8 inch is perfect for cornbread. A recipe with 1 cup of flour/cornmeal or just cornmeal fits pefectly.  I usually do two at a time. I just got my third 8 inch skillet. I will be using all 3 at once for an upcoming family function.1 cup cornmeal, 1 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp baking soda, 1/2 tsp salt, 1 Tbs sugar. 1 cup buttermilk, 1 egg, 2 Tbs oil. Preheat the skillet with the oven. Melt a couple of Tbs of butter in the skillet. Spray with cooking spray. In the oven at 400 for about 25 minutes or a little less. Let cool in the skillet for at least half an hour. Some cheese and green chilies in the batter are optional, but a good addition.As with all iron: Always PREHEAT!!. That is even more important than seasoning to limit sticking. Even though it comes with some seasoning give it at least 2 coats of additional seasoning. Never cook at too high a temperature unless you need to sear.For most dinner dishes I transfer the food into a serving dish and wash the piece with hot water and a brush andget it into an oven preheated to 425 degrees. I turn the oven off and eat. By the time it cools the piece or pieces are dry and sterile and the hardest cleanup done before I take my first bite of dinner.
title: Thought It Might Be Too Small, But It Isn't.

author: WitchyWomyn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2020
review_content: I love this little skillet. It arrived quickly and is well seasoned. I love cast iron to cook, but I have to confess I bought it for my cat. You see, she was homeless and showed up on our porch, and we took her in. We took her to the vet, got a clean bill of health, got her shots, and everybody was happy, except for kitty’s sore bum and our wallet. This kitty is very sweet and affectionate. But having lived on her own, her survival instincts are very strong. She feels she needs to hide her food so predators don’t find her. In trying to hide her food, she tries to cover it up, pawing all around it, she inevitably turns it over and then spills the dry food everywhere. We bought increasingly heavy food bowls, but she still knocked them off her table. Finally, my husband said to just accept it, we wouldn’t be able to keep her from turning the bowl over. Challenge accepted! Enter one cast iron frying pan. Her food bowl was placed inside the cast iron pan. That was the end of the food being turned over or pushed off the table. She still tries. She just can’t move the cast iron pan. If she ever stops, I’ll have a handy little frying pan!!
title: Excellent skillet!!

author: SaludaView
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2018
review_content: I am disappointed with this Lodge pan that I purchased from Amazon in August 2018. I followed all of the directions for using it. (I even used organic flaxseed oil on it, as recommended by Cook's Illustrated). My old 12-inch Lodge responds well to the flaxseed oil treatment, but it doesn't seem to have the same effect on this new eight-inch pan. After just four months of use, my eight-inch pan is half-rusted and half "almost-rusted". See photo. I'm wary of buying Lodge pans now;  I wonder if this is a genuine Lodge pan. I feel as if I wasted my money.
title: I am disappointed

author: Diff Family Reviews
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2018
review_content: I have probably used this pan 10 times in as many days.  Within 10 minutes of it being delivered I cleaned it with a little mild soap and rinsed it with warm water. I then made grilled cheese and ham. It was awesome.I then did a few passes of seasoning where I wiped it down with canola oil and baked it in the oven upside down at 350°.Next was fried chicken (stuck pretty bad), meatballs (no sticking), bacon (PERFECTION), sausage patties (great), home fries (stuck horribly), and then pizza which literally slid right out of the pan.The pan does not perform flawlessly right out of the gate and I did get some stickage, but with all the research I have done I kinda knew that was going to happen. You just have to keep going, and they say it's best to do a lot of deep frying in the beginning. If you stick to fatty meats, etc... you will be good to go and hopefully enough seasoning builds up to get some non stick home fries.The pan is a beast, 15 inches and 11.5 pounds. If you drop it on your foot, you might need a new foot. It'll make a horrible weapon as the handle is a little small for such a large heavy pan and I can see losing your grip very easily if swinging above your head.  The handle is actually a great size however for the stove as the pan is very large but the handle does not get in the way of other pans or dangerously hang off the edge. I originally thought the handle was too small but now I see why and I like it.
title: From one newbie to another

author: Jennifer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2020
review_content: I have to say this will be the first negative review I’m leaving on Amazon. I’m well aware not everything will be perfect through mail, but the packaging on these products was atrocious. Not only was there absolutely no packing materials between the two CAST IRON pans but there was barely any in the box. There’s a small scratch on the larger pan because the smaller one was sitting inside of it and probably rubbing the edges onto the other. The box didn’t look sturdy enough for a small rug let alone two roughly 10lb pans. Otherwise the pans are beautiful they look well made and very sturdy considering they held up in the cardboard box it was sent in. Will review the other pan good or bad if I have any issues or positive comments to make. Giving it a 4 because I’m unsure if this is an amazon mess up or the seller, don’t want to see a company have a bad review if it’s not even their fault.
title: Boxing could have been better
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 10.25-InchVerified Purchase

author: BeerCanChicken
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2017
review_content: For high heat cooking, there's really nothing better to cook with in an indoor kitchen. I've used most cookware, aside from copper and nothing I've tried comes close to providing the searing/browning ability of these cast iron skillets. Meat, roasted vegetables and stir-frys excel in these pans and the ability to go from stove-top to oven makes them even more versatile.But there are some drawbacks: they are quite heavy and somewhat high maintenance (ex. you can't throw in sink to clean the next morning, you're better off just leaving it on the stove then washing when you're able). They have to be completely dried after rinsing. Eggs are a challenge until it's very well seasoned and even then I don't think I'd use cast iron (I'm not down with brown eggs anyway). Acidic and tomato based items can also absorb the flavors of the pan and "un-season" it, making those types of food undesirable to use with these.And anyone complaining about serious sticking probably needs to revisit basic cooking science...the pan has to be preheated hot and what's going into the pan should patted dry and brought to room temperature, NOT directly out of the refrigerator cold. Also: you have to let things be. For instance, a steak (or whatever you're searing/browning should only be flipped once and it will become way easier to flip when the temperature of the pan and the food become close to the same
title: Best pan for high heat searing and roasting

author: OLdweeb
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2021
review_content: Lodge Pre-Seasoned Cast Iron Skillet, 10.25", Black:  It arrived completely uninsulated in an oversized box. Predictably the handle was broken off. But the return was problem free. The replacement looks great fulltime on my stove. There's a hot spot (verified by IR thermometer) that's consistent even between burners. I work around having 2 different temps simultaneously on the same burner, sometimes even using it to my advantage. Cleaning is relatively easy. Stubborn spots are removed with my chain mail scrubber & large crystal sea salt. Overall I'd rather use this quirky US made old fashioned skillet than a no name non-stick.
title: not quite as convenient as a modern non-stick but I prefer it nevertheless

author: Ld
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2020
review_content: This 13.25 is like Super  Big!! It’s so large  that it’s shocking when you open it. It’s awesome, but much larger than your mind thinks it will be. Haha! I love it’s for cooking a large brisket or a large amount of food for a family gathering. The original seasoning is good, but I decided to coat it with canola oil lightly and and toss it in the oven for one more coat of seasoning. If your thinking about it...Go for it and purchase it!!!But remember my review it’s huge!!!! Lol.. no lie
title: OMG!!!! HUGE!!!!

author: T. N. C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
review_content: The overwhelming positive reviews had me so excited to buy this for my husband. He used it once and found that it was not like his other cast iron pans....meaning the food REALLY stuck to the bottom of the pan (even though he used the same oils he always does with his other cast iron pans). It took a while, but he got it clean and felt that the cooking surface was too rough to get to food to slid off easily. SO... I bought my husband a new project... he sanded (or ground down) the rough bottom so its nice and smooth now. We are hoping after cleaning it and seasoning it again that it will work just like his other cast iron pans. Not a total loss and it could very well end up being a great pan... just a lot more work than we signed up for.
title: Not Exactly Great at First
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 10.25-InchVerified Purchase

author: D.K
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2019
review_content: This is probably the smallest sized pan most people will need.I can't imagine going any smaller than this personally. Youre looking at about a 6in actual cooking surface Id guess.I was really kinda iffy about even buying it to begin with, since I rarely cook just for myself, but for sub $10 add on, I thought what the heck.Glad I did!You can fry 2 eggs comfortably, or two normal size squares of liver mush(kinda tight), or 2 decent sausage patties(Grand's biscuit size), 4 slices of spam(corners touching), 1 egg and a couple of sausage links, etc.You get the idea.For 1 guy making a sandwich when leftovers or pizza night just isn't doin it for you, it is phenomenal.No need to pull out a larger pan.Also, this pan is beautiful at sautéing a medium onion. For that it seems nearly designed with that purpose in mind.It fits on the back burner of my coil-type electric stove perfectly as the 10.25in Lodge I have does on the front burner.With just a stove top type re-seasoning, with bacon drippings, this little pan slicked up amazing. One of the bestfinishes I have.
title: Superb little 8" pan

author: Rick D
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2021
review_content: This is a heavy, well made cast iron skillet just like my grandmother had.  That skillet was handed down to my mom and then to my sister.This Lodge skillet is that same quality.  This one will also be handed down through generations.  It's that good.Great preseasoning.  Washed it with Dawn and used it immediately.  It heated faster and more evenly than than the aluminum and stainless non-stick pans we have.  Cleaned up easily.And, I love the fact that Lodge is a family owned company that still manufactures everything here in the United States.
title: Excellent, large cast iron skillet

author: Kathi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2020
review_content: I can't describe how much I hate this pan.  I've wanted a good cast iron skillet for a while, this isn't one.  It claims to be NON STICK, completely false.  I've even tried on lowest heat possible and still, EVERYTHING sticks.  It comes preseasoned but suggests oil, which I used.  First time I used it, everything stuck horribly.  Took me crazy long to try and scrape as much as I could off of it.  I used some dish soap, which instructions say is okay but I'd always heard not to, but barely helped.  I read where you can oil it and bake it in the oven for around 50 minutes to help season it and help it keep food from sticking, but it didn't help one bit.  I barely cooked some eggs today and even over low heat everything STUCK completely to the pan.  I googled some more and read you can boil water in the pan for a few minutes to help loosen food and this helped some, but still can't get everything off of the pan.  I'll NOT use this again.  Miserable and frustrating product.
title: MOST DIFFICULT PAN I'VE EVER "TRIED" TO CLEAN!!!

author: Isaac Karjala
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2018
review_content: 5 stars for the pan, 1 star for the pot holder.this new design of pot holder is awful. the old design (mini inside out fabric oven mit..... basically) worked well because you could slip it on and off of the pan's handle easily without having to directly touch the pan. This, no. If you try putting this on the pan without using your opposing hand to keep the pan from moving it will push the pan off the burner rather than sliding over the handle. Same story taking it off. So basically, you need an oven mit anyway which really reduces the utility having the pot holder to nearly pointless.
title: amazon automatically titles reviews that aren't titled by the author. the auto-title for this one was so bad I had to change it.
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 8-InchVerified Purchase

author: bluegrass mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2021
review_content: I was surprised at how often we use this little pan. When I ordered this pan, I thought that we would occasionally use it because it is so small. But this is just the right size for a couple fried eggs, a can of refried beans, a pound of ground meat, a small side dish for the family or to warm up leftovers for one person. I'm pretty sure that we use this almost everyday.This would be the ideal size for an individual or a couple but also useful as an extra for a family.It came pre-seasoned and ready to use. Because it's cast iron, it heats evenly. I have bought cheaper cast iron skillets before but they are rougher and it takes awhile to get it smooth enough to not stick. But with the Lodge brand, I know that I can trust their quality and they are consistently smooth enough to use immediately. Because it's so smooth it's also easy to clean.
title: Love this little pan!

author: Nicole in WI
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2020
review_content: I bought the 13in Lodge skillet and I love it. It’s heavy and you’ll probably want to get silicone covers for the handles. It’s very heavy. I have a ceramic cook top so I’m careful to not slide the skillet around on the stove. I haven’t had any scratches but I’ve read it’s possible on these stove tops.I feel like an idiot for not trying cast iron sooner. I cook eggs a ton and I thought it couldn’t be done well in cast iron. I was wrong. I can tilt this pan and slide my eggs out most of the time. It does require some prep to get to this level of non-stick though.When the pan arrived I covered it in the thinnest layer of canola oil I could and baked it at 400F for an hour. Over several days I did this 7 times. Some say that’s overkill but my skillet is hella non-stick now. Just make sure to use oil/butter to cook sticky foods like eggs and wipe the pan out while it’s still warm. Always dry it completely as it will rust quickly, but rust can be removed from these fairly easily.
title: A very good investment

author: Kelly Hair
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2021
review_content: Love Lodge's cast iron skillets. Excellent quality. Figure the grandkids will own it one day.  The silicon handle works well too.I've converted my "non stick only" wife to it as well. The only criticism she has is that it's heavy. While true, I find cast iron much easier to clean that "non stick" pans that may work for a year and crap out.A plastic scrapper, chain mail scrubber and some vegetable oil make cleaning & keeping clean a breeze.
title: Lodge quality
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: JA
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2020
review_content: So this is my first ever cast iron pan - after years of having a ceramic stovetop I now have a gas one and lost my last excuse.  I've had the pan about a week now and love everything about it.As a first time cast iron user I read a lot of the reviews here and seasoned it in the "cathartic" method (nice review bud!) - heated the pan, rubbed it down with oil and then let it preheat in the oven @ 475, left it for an hour after it preheated and then shut off the oven, left it in there until cool.  Did this three times over a couple days, got a lovely black sheen.  I even "messed up" the first time, using too much oil and too little time - to help anyone else who makes the same mistake if you end up with a "tacky" pan, simply lightly oil it again and bake it off in the oven just as if you were seasoning - came out perfect!As far as cooking goes - I've had a blast using it.  My first ever meal was steak and cheese - got that nice hard crispy brown "steak shop" crust on the shaved steak, delicious!  Next up was attempting a filet and ribeye - again awesome hard brown (not burned!) sear on the exterior and perfect medium / midrare on both (filet went in first, ribeye shortly after).  The last thing was an omelet.  With all this, I've heated up the pan on medium low, added in fat after smoking then added in whatever I was cooking... and it's come out perfectly.  The omelet floated right up above the bacon fat and slid right out of the pan when done!  Awesome!One thing I was worried about was cleaning - knowing I can't use soap and fearful there'd be tons of grit on the bottom had me thinking post-dinner cleanup would be a pain - but it's been so simple.  There's very little stuck to the pan (even the omelet left only a small amount of egg) and the stainless steel "chainmail" scrubber I bought with the pan works wonders.  It hasn't been a chore to clean at all, and it was something I was worried about (would the pan never hit the stove if it was a 30 minute process to clean after cooking, eating, dishes, etc?).  Instead, it's almost fun to go through the ritual of scrub, dry, heat and oil (yes I heat the pan after cleaning then rub it down with a tiny bit of oil).So, overall this thing is a bit like a kitchen gremlin, what with all the initial rules and such... but the results are fantastic so far.  It's a joy to cook with and I actually like the little niceties of caring for it.  Like any other tool, take care of it and it will take care of you!
title: Love This Pan!

author: kattyface
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2020
review_content: I was hesitant to buy after the mixed reviews, but if you take the time to season the skillet properly you shouldn’t have any issues. Take the time to: (1) thoroughly scrub the skillet with soap and water [ONLY THIS ONE TIME FOR THE HISTORY OF YOUR SKILLET), then place in a 450 oven for a few minutes to dry, then (2) wipe an extremely thin coat of vegetable oil all over the skillet [top and bottom], buffing it in and wiping off any excess, then bake in 450 oven for 30 minutes, then (3) repeat step 2 so that the skillet has been coated/baked for a total of four times. Boom, you’re ready to go.
title: Season properly for a good experience

author: looki
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2021
review_content: It is amazing just how big this is. I was torn between this and the 17 inch and finally decided on this because of the handle.I figure with the longer handle it will be easier to move it around on the camp fire.The interior finish is usable as is, but all Lodge products are rougher that I like so I always sand them down with a power sander. I don't sand every bump out. Just enough to give me a smooth enough surface to turn eggs on. Yes you do have to reseason the pan after you sand it.I'm kind of spoiled when it comes to finishes on cast iron cookware, because I own a fry pan and a dutch oven that were my grandmother's and they are glass smooth inside.
title: What a beast, this thing can cook for the whole crowd.

author: Cindy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2020
review_content: This pan is not really seasoned.  I don't know how any of them can be until they've been cooked in.  This pan is tremendous now that it's been seasoned.  What I did:  Wash the pan and make sure it's dry.  I put it on the cooktop burner for a couple of minutes to dry it.  Then coat it with a THIN coat of canola oil.  Cover the entire pan, handles, top and bottom.  Place it into the oven upside down at 500° for 1 hour.  Turn off the oven and leave it in there to cool.  Do that process about 5-6 times.  Also, begin to cook with it.  Using butter or oil will help the seasoning process.  After a week or two the pan will be properly seasoned.  To clean it, never use soap.  I use a plastic scraper from Walmart or a soap-free sponge.  Then dry it and add a tiny bit of oil to the inside of the pan and store until the next use.  You'll begin to love using cast iron.  It's the safest thing to cook with and the most affordable, unless you can afford a $100+ Smithey pan.
title: Always reliable Lodge cast iron pan.

author: Teaanyoung Zhou
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
review_content: Love it. I've had these for two years. Initially I thought I got scammed because how rough the surface looked. Now I've changed my mind. I learned to be patient and let the food release themselves. As shown in the picture, I made egg based Chinese crepes (or pancake?) in them. The whole thing comes off completely without sticking anywhere and it's crispy on the ouside and soft inside.I got a lodge wok too. It takes a longer time to heat the whole thing up because it's deep. I imagine on fire it will be wonderful.I use this about once a week, because I use my instant pot a lot. And I don't use them for making steaks often because that creates too much smoke for my little apt. But for the time that I did make steak in them when j first bought them. They were amazing. The steak will initially stick on it and then release themselves after browned.As for cleaning, there are lots of YouTube videos. For tough stains, I used salt scrubbing and boiling water. They all work. If you cleaned them too much, the seasoning will come off. I'm at the point when I don't need to wash them like that any more. It's non stick. I just rinse it with hot water some times with soft sponge and heat it up and season them.
title: As advertised

author: Kenny Moore
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2021
review_content: 6.5" is just the right size for a tiny MSR-style camping stove - also for cooking for one. My 6.5" aluminum cook kit lid fits it well. And, it is sooo cute (according to my daughter). Buyers of any cast iron skillet should be aware ...- Handle gets *hot* - have a potholder handy- "Pre-seasoned" means lightly seasoned - could use some more. I did three cycles using avocado oil.- The nonstick surface has it's limits - I don't recommend using it to scramble eggs.- Acidic stuff like tomato sauce is hard on the patina.- No soap - wash with hot water and a gentle non-scratch cloth or pad. Dry immediately and well.- Apply light coating of oil after every few uses to prevent rust.
title: Great value, high quality

author: Mark
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2017
review_content: Good quality cast iron.  As with all cast iron cookware the key is keeping them seasoned properly.  Once seasoned you must watch how you wash them, (no dish washer, no soap, only hot water and a nylon scrubber works best for me) and re-season them after washing.  Once you get the hang of it, it becomes second nature.  Cooking with cast iron will also add dietary iron to your meals.  I am low in iron but cannot take iron supplements as they upset my stomach.  But cooking in cast iron helps keep my iron levels up.
title: Good quality cast iron

author: Rosa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2020
review_content: Very impressed/relived over the quality, especially because I purchased it used. The pan itself is of exactly the same build/quality as the one seen in the pictures and all the other Lodge cast irons vids/pics posted on the internet.Now, I bought mine “used/like new,” and I’ll be honest, part of me was worried, even though I know people go and buy or inherent used/antique cast iron pans all the time. It’s hard not to worry when you can’t really see just how “used/like new” the item your buying is, especially when it’s an item that can easily rust if mistreated/mishandled.I’m glad to share that my specific pan had little to no scratches and it seemed as though it hadn’t been seasoned or cooked on by it’s previous owner.I’m hoping this means it was returned because of the previous owner was either comparing different cast irons brands in person or because of some other misunderstanding when it came to pan size/quantity/material/etc.Either way, so hype, and so very very pleased.
title: I’m highkey honored to finally have a cast iron pan of my own. Thank you Lodge.

author: Bee Sunny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2021
review_content: I was intimidated by the thought of taking care of cast iron, so I bought a black carbon steel pan first. The seasoning kept wearing off and it smelled like steel at times, plus it wasn't flat. I don't have any of those problems with this pan, and it was about a third of the price too. It's heavy but manageable because of the helper handle. I also love the short handle, which means it fits flat in my sink for cleaning (I have a standard 2-bowl stainless sink). Because it's so nonstick, it's easy to clean. I've just been using a nylon scrubber without soap and then wiping the inside with oil using a paper napkin after each cleaning. Easy peasy.
title: Completely happy

author: Bryan ck
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2020
review_content: There's something special about looking at someone cooking on a skillet and you can tell right away that hundreds if not thousands of meals have been made on it, the more you cook on it the better it gets and if you mess up and burn something just scrape it off, it can handle it and it sometimes even smooths it out for you giving you a nice smooth surface. When you buy one look into "seasoning" your skillet, just youtube it, that being said never ever wash your skillet unless you are going to spend the time drying it thoroughly and then heating it up and then covering it in a thin layer of oil, you choose till you find what you like. I love mine, ive had it just over a year and i try to cook on it as much as possible, the more you cook the smoother the surface gets and food eventually comes off like butter. this is all my opinion, do with it as you will, i love this item and i try to buy it for other family members so they can enjoy it as well.
title: Buy it to pass it down to your kids!

author: D. S. Kusted
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2020
review_content: The only thing you need to be aware of is that the handle does get very hot so you do need to use an oven mitt or potholder.Performance wise the pan works beautifully.I grew up in Erie, Pa. the home of the now long out of business Griswald cast iron cookware company. Until finding the lodge skillet I have never found any that cooked as well as a Griswald. Now however, I have found a comparable frying pan the cooks evenly and cleans up nicely. It comes ready to use and is seasoned with lubrication. All you need to do is a quick wash and you are ready to make some delicious food. The steady even heat provided by cast iron cannot be beat when it comes to results. Happy cooking to all who decide to choose this cookware. I really do think you will be pleased.
title: I couldn’t be more satisfied.

author: Richard Middleton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2021
review_content: This is an ideal small skillet for almost any food;  I use it for dishes ranging from blackened catfish to flatbread fried in ghee.  Obviously it can go on the barbecue, which many skillets made of other materials cannot.  It has enough depth to retain oil or fat for cooking, something that can be very difficult to achieve with flat skillets.  It's heavier than aluminum or other materials, but you expect that from cast iron, and in return it gives excellent distribution of heat.  It's easy to clean, provided that you follow instructions and educate yourself about cooking with cast iron:  I've been using cast iron cookware for over 50 years now and have never had problems with rust.  Generally an excellent product at a hard-to-beat price.
title: Great for cooking inside or out

author: jr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2019
review_content: 3.5" = for the fully awesome breakfast sandwich size egg!!!For us:  lard or tallow is the best LODGE lubricant - especially while breaking-in the pan + we add some unsalted butter as well for additional flavor.Made in USA Lodge = best Cookware Value EVER - we use it mostly these days,  & we hardly ever touch our much more expensive 'premium brands' cookware ....Made in the USA LODGE Cookware:  learn how to care for it = UNEQUALED for most Stovetop & many Oven preparations.each to their own .... but why pay more for less???ps.  we have many other Lodge pan sizes & love them all - but we especially love a easy-peasy & delicious homemade breakfast sandwich nearly everyday - making this (3.5") - the most used of them all!
title: Absolutely Loooovvvvveeee all the - Made in the USA / Lodge Cookware!

author: Joy May
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2021
review_content: I have a sixty year old cast iron skillet that I prefer for a lot of cooking and baking except that it has a slight rim on the bottom which keeps it from sitting flat on a glass top stove. The man-sized skillet is flat bottom and does not have cool spots, but it is too heavy to lift when full of gravy. I have not tried the lodge on top of the stove yet for even distribution of heat, but will this week. The Lodge skillet is flat bottomed and the shape is a little different. All three of my cast iron skillets are made in USA. Two are antiques. The Lodge is new. I'm trusting the metal content to be safe in all three. I would love to try them out on a wood burning range in the winter months if I had a place for one in my kitchen.  When they get greasy and grubby from too much frying, I stick them in the red hot coals of the wood heating stove and burn all that off. Then I reseason them per instructions. They look like new for a while.
title: Like the shape, weight and flat bottom

author: Lindsey M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2021
review_content: It’s light enough (but durable/tough enough) to double as an easily usable self defense weapon, without putting excessive strain on yourself while defending your fort. Lol. Really, it’s a great size and weight for anyone who might have trouble lifting/moving/cleaning standard size cast iron pans. It’s the perfect size for smaller portions, or when you’re only cooking for 1-3, maybe 4 people. It’s a great way to raise iron levels in the body, and Lodge is my favorite brand for cast iron. I do appreciate that these comes pre-seasoned, however since I had to cut soy out of my diet, I strip and reseason with tallow or lard or olive oil.
title: Perfect!

author: Amature Alto Actress
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2021
review_content: I knew cast iron was heavy, but this very difficult to pick up with one hand and hard to take out and put away, especially in a lower cabinet. Food cooks well in this pan. It’s supposedly seasoned, but obviously not very well. Everything sticks to it.
title: Good pan but it weighs more than me.
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: C Stanton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2021
review_content: When this was delivered I was not sure if it was for me for the following reasons:1. It was delivered in no packaging2. There was no discernable label3. It was not BSA branded4. The tracking number provided was apparently incorrect and showed a delivery date days away and a location half way across the countryOtherwise the pan - after I cleaned it because who knows what it came in contact with - heats quickly and evenly and has not warped. I've done a number of steaks, searing on the stove and right into a 425 degree oven without any issues. The heat distribution is probably better than the BSA one because the BSA one has the logo on the bottom of the pan.
title: Not what I asked for but good anyways

author: A Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2021
review_content: Perfect size for 1 fried or a couple scrambled eggs. I have already used it to make country gravy as well.  Lodge is top quality cast iron and is SUPER easy to care for. People say it’s chipped and rusty and that is their fault.  Cast iron is super durable and it takes a heck of a beating to chip it.  The seasoning will chip off and it will rust if it is scrubbed with an abrasive and it’s not dried after each use. A simple dish cloth and some hot water with a tiny bit of dawn dishwash will clean it perfectly. It should never be left to sit, wash it immediately after using and ABSOLUTELY no dishwasher!!!  After a quick wash put a little oil on a paper towel and wipe around the entire skillet and put away.  I put all mine in the drawer below the oven.  I have been using my Grandmothers lodge skillets for 25 years and have never once had an issue.  The new ones I’ve added (only LODGE!) no problems.  The only reason the “off brand” as I call it doesn’t work for me is that they are super rough in the cooking area of the pan.  You can use a power sander to smooth it out but you have to go back and re-season and that’s too much of a hassle. I want to be able to use mine out of the box and know I’m using a top quality product.  Amazon had awesome prices on Lodge and it even goes on sale at times and I grab it up. You can never have too many!!  They cook your food like no other from frying, cooking steaks, baking pies and breads to soups and stews they can’t be beat!
title: Perfect lil skillet by Lodge

author: SimplySky
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2018
review_content: Supreme quality cast iron. It's a little heavy for me and my husband and I both have to use two hands when moving it around but we just love this cast iron.And one of the best added perks is we noticed this is the same skillet Chef John from foodwishes.com uses! We were very tickled to see we bought the same skillet as our favorite celebrity chef! This skillet was also recommended by America's Test Kitchen. So you know it's good!
title: Excellent cast iron skillet

author: Gman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2020
review_content: Right off the bat, people should know this thing is SMALL!  It's advertised as 6 1/2 in, but that's across the top (and, actually, it's only 6 3/8 in).  The base is only 5 in, so it won't even cover the small burners on an electric range.  That being said, it's a great cast iron skillet.  Perfect for my two egg breakfast.  I did use plenty of butter to fry them in, but who doesn't like butter (yes, bacon grease would even be better)?  And the little bit of egg that stuck to the bottom scraped off easily with my plastic spatula (this was the first time I used it, so as time goes by, there should be even less sticking).  Then a few drops of flaxseed oil rubbed over the pan, and done!  The price was great, and it's made in the US...what's not to like?
title: Yep, it's tiny!

author: cherikokusu
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2020
review_content: Definitely a one-person serving pan, as the 8 inches is just barely enough to cook two medium sized chicken breasts. but as one person who uses this pan, this is the BEST pan for cooking meat - hands down. I take good care of it, every once in a while i clean and season the pan, and after every use i scrub WITHOUT soap just elbow grease and a brush. If there's stuck food on the pan just pour a little water in it, leave the water simmering on the stove while ya eat, and scrub it off again.I wouldn't call this a non-stick pan but i use a pastry brush to brush a little oil on every time i use it and that does the trick to keep most food from sticking. a little food might still stick though, get over it.EDIT: Almost a year later I still love this pan. Use it everyday. Good as new because I wash it right after I use it and keep it nice and oiled. Love your cast iron and your cast iron will love u back.
title: New favorite pan: EASY to clean

author: dodd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2019
review_content: I love the size of this skillet, it's exactly what I was looking for. Perfect for small meals. Only problem is there is a tiny chip on the top of the rim, hardly noticeable but I'm afraid over time it will rust. Although I haven't used it yet, I threw away all the packaging before I noticed the chip. There is no way to send a message to the seller so I'm probably stuck with this flawed little skillet. Otherwise I would give it 5 stars as there is nothing like cooking on cast iron and Lodge is the best brand on the market.UPDATE: Now that I've used this pan my rating went down to 1 star, only because there's no option for zero. It has the Lodge label on it but it's just not up to the quality I'm used to from this brand. It wasn't well seasoned when I got it which is odd. My biggest concern is after washing, black residue comes off the pan onto the paper towel when I dry it. And I mentioned the chip on top of the rim, now there's another one and it hasn't been bumped or anything. These chips look like paint chipping off. Not sure how this defective pan got through inspection but I wouldn't buy one on Amazon again. You're just never sure what you're getting. If I had purchased this in a retail store I could have exchanged it.
title: As Expected but One Flaw

author: Amanda Snow
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: This skillet has become my favorite! I will admit that there's a slight learning curve to cooking with cast iron but really, it's super simple and I'm always amazed at the fact that things don't stick! I had a cheaper skillet and it had gotten some rusty places, even though I was drying it properly when I washed it. Also the center of that skillet was slightly raised and the oil or sauce would run to the edges. It's been so wonderful to have a proper skillet! I love that it is preseasoned. It cleans up perfectly every time! I love the little silicone handle protector too. I use this skillet on a glass top stove and it hasn't scratched it or anything. I'm careful not to slide it though. In short, this thing is worth every penny!
title: My favorite skillet!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: R. Claros
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2017
review_content: We've been wanting a smaller cast iron skillet for a while. This is perfect when cooking for one.  The texture is rough and it does come pre-seasoned.  HOWEVER -YOU MUST SEASON FURTHER!!!!  Cast iron rusts easily, so take the time to re-season a few more times.  Easiest by far is to ALWAYS leave a teaspoon or two of your favorite oil in the skillet, and leave the skillet on the stove.  Heat up your skillet before using with the oil, and it will naturally season itself over time.  The other option is to do 3 or 4 coats of seasoning by placing a light layer of oil, baking the skillet at 350 or 400 degrees for an hour or two, let it cool and repeat.About the rough texture; after seasoning further, it does not cause any problems.  It still becomes non-stick.  We use metal utensils on it, and over time our larger skillet has become very smooth, but there is no difference in non-stick ability.If you have an electric stove - BE CAREFUL - Iron skillets will warp if you leave them on "high" for more than a few minutes.  We don't go behond 7 or 8 on our stove.
title: Good - becomes excellent with a little more care

author: nzbeezy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2020
review_content: This pan is a perfect lil’ size!! It fits 1 burger or 1 filet/tenderloin cut of steak. Great to make a frittata for 2 (or 1 if you love protein like me).It fits in my oven next to a regular sized cookie sheet sideways, which is convenient for utilizing a single tray in your oven. Especially if you have a double oven.Not sure about a chicken breast or a lamb sausage. I think the chicken will have to be curled and same with the sausage. Lol. Ok going to stop writing before this gets weird! Buy the pan, can’t go wrong for $8!Also it’s light enough to take on a camping trip ;)
title: Perfect for small gourmet meals

author: Michelle Washington
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2016
review_content: I can't even believe how tiny and cute this skillet is, you guys! I am already the proud owner of three Lodge products, two 12 inch cast iron skillets and a 7 quart cast iron Dutch oven. I love their cast iron products, so naturally, that's where I looked first to find a tiny skillet.You're probably wondering what I would need with a 3.5 inch miniature cast iron skillet. Well, I'll tell ya. My husband comes up with these... let's call them "ideas" and he wanted to try to melt all of his scrap metal shavings into one solid piece. He read that he could use a small cast iron skillet for that. He has a bunch of scrap brass, carbon, etc laying around in various containers so for his sake, I hope his project works.Btw, he's definitely not doing it in the house! He has some little contraption that he built outside by our fire pit. Luckily, we live in the country so we could do country stuff like that. HahahaJust for kicks, I will let y'all know how it works out. :)
title: Cutest little thing I ever did see

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2016
review_content: I was so excited to get this in the mail. I've owned several cast iron skillets, molds, what have you. Our last one of this size pitted(it was ancient), and there was no coming back and I didn't realize how important this size was until we no longer had it, so I ordered another. It arrived with a crack. So disappointed. I had already thrown all tags away and begun to cook with it when I realized. I'm going to use it anyway it's just frustrating because it's not like this item was cheaper than you can find elsewhere. CHECK YOUR SKILLET BEFORE TEARING THE TAGS.
title: CHECK YOUR SKILLET FOR CRACKS

author: PTB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2020
review_content: Great Price!The pandemic started me on a wonderous cooking adventure. A cast iron skillet was my next step in this cooking revolution. The price was amazing, half the # of sheckles compared to similar sized. 1st thing I cooked was bacon, to really lock in the seasoning. I've since cooked 3 total dishes & they all came out fantastic. Heating seems to be pretty even.I like that the handle is not tilted upwards, so it fits easily into an oven.It's so heavy, I would use it as a weapon during the inevitable Zombie Apocalypse!
title: Heavy enough to Zombies!

author: Matt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2021
review_content: This is the itchen beast you always wanted. Fry, saute, bake, etc. I got tired of replacing "non-stick" pans even if I use oil. The problem is heat and oil always seem to degrade the non stick surface. Even if I avoid using the sprays which have additives that gum up the surface, I have the same problem. I suggest you "season" this more when it is received by cooking with some oil til it smokes then clean it with just some water and wipe dry with a paper towel. You also should used enough oil with a high smoke point when cooking with it - not too hot as it retains heat. Other than that, I doubt I'll ever need to buy any additional pans as my lids fit from the old ones.
title: The OG of the Kitchen

author: Familyof4
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2020
review_content: Ive been wanting one of these cast iron pans for awhile but hesitated because of how heavy they are. Finally decided to try this one. So happy with it so far. Takes awhile to season but after that, its a great pan. Best thing is to never wash these with soap. I seasoned it cooking bacon. Now it works so well and I don't even have to use butter on my grilled cheeses. My mac and cheese turned out so yummy in this. So simple to clean with a paper towel and some water. Great pan even if I can barely lift it.
title: Great product

author: yini
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2020
review_content: This skillet is absolutely amazing! I cleaned it and seasoned it the first day it came, and it did not stick at all! After every use, I clean it with hot water, put it on the stove to heat dry, and then apply a very thin of vegetable oil. It only takes about 2 minutes to take care for it, but the result is wonderful!For those who may want to know how to season the skillet the very first time, here are my steps:1. Pour water in the skillet and put it on the stove until the water boiling for a few minutes. -- clean the inside2. Discard the water, then pour another cup of hot water with baking soda to clean it out. -- clean inside/outside3. Put the skillet on the stove to heat dry and apply a thin layer of vegetable oil on both sides. -- season4. Put the skillet in the preheated 450F oven for 1 hour.  -- make the oil dissolve into the small pores on the skillet, which is critical to turn the skillet nonsticky!
title: Wish I had bought it earlier, such an amazing skillet!

author: Curious
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2020
review_content: The more I use it, the better it gets. Eggs cook beautifully and just slide off the pan, the high heat will sear a steak beautifully, vegetables roast to a lovely brown without sticking, and cornbread develops a golden crust.  It’s not the best pan for everything, but it has become my favorite pan when I need more than just heating something up. To maintain the pan and make sure it’s always ready to work, after cooking I give it a quick gentle scrub with a gentle scrubbing sponge (the type I use for non-stick dishes) making sure not to scrape the delicate seasoning surface, dry with a towel and then heat it on the burner for a couple of minutes to make sure it’s dry — then I wipe it down with a light coat of oil while it’s hot.
title: Better and better with each use, after washing I oil and heat it for next time
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Jessica
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2021
review_content: It’s my first cast iron pan so I didn’t know how to care for it fully, but I figured it out. It cannot be left to air dry or it will rust. It has to be dried of with towels, and I also spread a bit of olive oil on the surface of the pan after I dry it off to help prevent rusting. It’s heavy and awkward but it cooks pretty well, especially meat. Needs a bit of time to heat up completely, but I use it a lot to fry up chicken or turkey bacon. I wish I knew what I was getting into before I bought it, but now that I know how to take care of it, I’m starting to appreciate it so much more than the non stick skillet I have.
title: Needs more tlc than other pans.
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 8-InchVerified Purchase

author: Hannah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2021
review_content: This is the only skillet I use.  This particular brand is good quality.  I’m a big fan of cast iron skillets as they’re quite versatile. Pros: 1- naturally non-stick if you keep it conditioned (brush a thin layer of vegetable oil before use and after cleaning) and also make sure it’s well heated before use.  2- can use stove top or in oven.  3- heats evenly, no cold and hot spots as with some lightweight skillets, so Food cooks evenly.  Cons: 1-  it’s heavier than most non cast iron skillets so may not be suitable for everyone. 2- handle gets hot; must use a potholder. 3- not dishwasher safe (but fairly easy to clean.)
title: Good quality!!

author: elkutsch
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2021
review_content: After making a pretty crowded meal in my 10 inch cast iron pan I decided to upgrade. Getting a 12 inch didn't seem like much of an upgrade, so I opted for the 15. This pan is massive. Not a Lodge issue at all, it is just way bigger than I had imagined it being. I have found that it works great for sides on my grill, and it will be super handy if I ever just need a giant fry pan for something.Since this purchase I have also bought the 12 inch. I think the 12 will get used more, but this beast of a pan will for sure have its place in my future cooking.
title: This thing is huge!

author: Adam R.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2020
review_content: Very happy with this purchase. A sturdy, solid, cast iron skillet. The only things that could be slightly improved: the handle of the skillet is a little shorter than I was anticipating, which means it's sometimes difficult to get good leverage on the pan (especially when hot) and the skillet is really heavy. I would personally have preferred a slightly longer handle / lever to make gripping / lifting / tilting a little easier on the wrist. Also, the seasoning that the pan comes with from the factory isn't the best. With a little TLC, however, and plenty of oil (or lard) that is easily overcome with a little patience and effort. Overall, happy with this product as it is a solid, well constructed cast iron skillet.
title: Great cast iron skillet, but the seasoning the pan comes with is not the best

author: Carl S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2020
review_content: This 10.25" Lodge cast iron skillet was under $15 shipped.  I don't care if you don't think the seasoning is perfect, or the shape isn't perfect or whatever.  That is by far the best deal going on American made cast iron cookware.Yes, the cooking surface of the Lodge is rougher than some of the other American made brands of cast iron.  But it cost under $15.  The next best price on American cast iron is near, or just over, $100.  Take a little time to re-season the lodge and it, too, will be just as smooth.Lodge cookware, for most people, is ready to go out of the box (aside from an initial washing).  It's well made and it's durable.  And nobody comes close to the price.I have a cabinet full of Lodge cookware, and I have some of the higher end pieces.  When it comes down to it, the higher end stuff may look more pleasing but doesn't function any better than the Lodge.You can't go wrong with Lodge cast iron.
title: Best Bang for the Buck

author: Tom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2020
review_content: I have owned one of these pans for 5 years. It takes a little getting used to the differences in care between non-stick and cast iron. In the end you will never need another pan. It requires extra heating/cooling time, a little extra oil, a little extra elbow grease, and bigger muscles to move it around. It will last your entire life with a some extra care, but you never have to worry about the harmful chemical surface flecking off and leeching into your food. Plus the more you use it the better it gets. You can't hurt it with a metal utensil, and the heat stays in it for searing and simmering.I got my son the 9" pan a few years ago, and the only thing he does not like about it is the smaller size. So I got him the 12" skillet and he loves it. One of my friends saw and also bought one.In a time when cheap, short-lived non-stick pans are plentiful, and high quality stainless steel requires a loan, Lodge cast iron skillets are a great alternative. I trust them to be made from reliable iron, and they are only a few dollars more than imported versions that I feel may not have trustworthy materials. (why do they all smell like diesel fuel?)
title: You never need to buy another pan
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Helen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2021
review_content: I needed a larger iron frying pan.  The one I have was my grandmothers  and is often too small for my needs i had been hesitant to order a new one because many of the new pans I see are not the quality of the old ones; but this pan has exceeded my expectations!  The pan came quickly in perfect condition . . . and pre-seasoned!  I used it the same evening and was very pleased.  It is exceptional quality (heavy due to its size), and good great.  It also is nonstick since pre-seasoned, and washes easily.  Taking proper care of these great iron pans enables you to use them for years, and then pass them down generations.  Love this pans!!
title: My favorite!

author: Emma Hunter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2020
review_content: I didn't inherit my mom's ancient cast iron frying pan and I tried replacing it with a low end new one. Disastrous. I seasoned i, babied it, and it was still a rusty, nasty, dirty disaster and threw it out. Over they years,  I've spent more than I care to admit on higher end cookware and have never gotten close to the performance of mom's  cast iron both for cooking (especially searing) and clean up. (I won't use nonstick surfaces for health concerns.) I came across an article on Lodge and decided to try again. I've cleared my cabinets of most of my stainless steel andI now have  2 10", and a 12" in frying pans (nice and deep!), and the Lodge ceramic dutch oven. Read and follow the guidance and after a few months of use, you'll be amazed how easily cleanup is. I pour a few inches of water in the pan after use, enjoy my meal, and clean up using The Ringer metal mesh. This level of performance for this price? Hard to believe.
title: Value & Performance

author: Tony E.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2021
review_content: This one was a gift.  We've gifted my kids with Lodge pans now for some years.At home we got five Lodge pans: 3 cast iron and 2 carbon steel... the 10" deep cast iron is my go to for about 50% of my cooking.  Extremely useful pans.Oh, we use a Viking range with big burners.  So the pans get hot pretty quickly and then retain the heat very well.  Even the carbon steel pans too.Naturally non stick.  But you do have to season them a bit and take care of them.However, if you don't know how to care of pans.. then, heck, why are you reading this?  It's frozen section of the supermarket and microwave oven for you!  ;-)
title: One Cast Iron To Rule Them All.

author: Melanie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2020
review_content: I love my skillet. I was scared of cast iron because you don't use soap to clean it. I haven't had a problem at all. I bought a stiff, dish-scrubbing brush that I only use for the cast iron. That way it never has soap on it. I have found warm water with the stiff brush works just fine. Then, dry it off immediately.I have made burgers, fried bacon, made cream sauces, tomato sauces, etc. Everything tastes really good in the cast iron.The one thing that doesn't work for me is eggs. I fried eggs in it using plenty of oil. They did stick. They tasted fine, but they stuck. I made scrambled eggs in it, and I didn't like the flavor. It took on the flavor from the seasoning. I am not sure a cast iron skillet works well for eggs.I have a Calphalon dutch oven, and I discovered my lid from that fits the Lodge skillet. That was convenient as I made one steamed dish that needed a lid. If you have other brands in cookware, you might be able to use the lids from them as the sizing seems standard.
title: I wish I had bought an iron skillet sooner.

author: A. Hutchins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2018
review_content: I would have given this a better review closer to when I first bought it. It seems the seasoning is coming off. It looks kind of bad. My other cheapie thrift store cast iron pan does a lot better. Haven't done anything weird. I usually season after every use and never use soap on it, but I left it as it was after washing so you can see the damage to the seasoning.
title: Just isn't lasting
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: The Gray Adder
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review_content: I have several Lodge cast iron skillets in my kitchen.  They just work.  Well.  The longer you use them, the better they get.  Eggs, pancakes, steak, burgers, all cook well with minimal additional oil without sticking. The best part, though, is that they are practically indestructible.  I have a cast iron skillet that I bought at a consignment store for $15 that's 150 years old and still works - that's how good these are, that your great-grandchildren will still find them useful.  So why buy another one?  Because I don't have a 12-inch skillet.
title: Cast iron FTW!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: HgChild
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: I had never owned cast iron before; Several Family Members did but cautioned about the clean up and keeping it well-oiled. I bought this and I love it!!! Honestly keep it on my stovetop at all times due to using it so much... Heats nicely, goes into the oven for chili with cornbread topping.  It works well for chicken and veggies...This is the perfect size for 2- 3 people. I would go up in size for a family of 4 or for larger portion sizes...I do keep pot holders next to me since the handle gets hot!!! Also I bought welding/camping gloves for oven-use. I haven't needed to use them, regular pot holders work fine for the high heat ... I use Dawn Powerwash to help loosen any stuck on bits... I also use Canola Spray on it after I wash and dry it to keep it oiled and ready to go...
title: Great Purchase!!

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2020
review_content: Only been cooking in iron a few years. My go to pans inside and outside at the bbq. It's a Lodge.  What more to say.  If your on a budget, Amazon Basic is a not a bad product.  Go for them. I have a number of them. But, I found i was happier after grinding them smooth and seasoning a few times.  They have ridges more then bumps on the finish which food tends to stick to.  Over all, Lodge just out preforms them out of the box.  Lodge has a much better seasoning from the factory. AND, Lodge is AMERICAN made.  That was important enough for me to pay a little more or wait for a sale.
title: Lodge vs. Amazon Basic

author: RenoReviewer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2020
review_content: My first new cast iron pan and after some consideration and a deal push in this direction I am not sorry for taking the plunge!  This pan came preseasoned which was awesome.  Care is easy and is virtually nonstick from the start.This pan WILL GET VERY HOT!  If you’re not use to cooking on cast iron, you’re in for a shock if you don’t have proper hand protection even when you think it’s cooled enough to handle. Follow all instructions for use to the letter and you’re going to have a pan for life!  And it’s true... it gets better each and every time you use it!Enjoy great food and a one vessel option for your best cooking ahead!
title: What have I done without this thing?

author: reviewer of stuff
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2019
review_content: Update 7/11/2020:Still love this little pan! After only a few times cooking with it, it became well-seasoned. Didn't have to season it in the oven. As long as I have a little bit of fat coating it, my egg doesn't stick no matter how high the cooking temp. I've used it nearly every day for months. <3The only thing I'd improve upon it is to lengthen the handle. It's very short, so using an oven mit is unweildy. I don't handle the pan when hot, because if this. I just use a spatula or fork to carefully lift food from it.Original review:This pan is the perfect size for one fried egg (with some cheese and an English muffin, you've got the basic fixings of a great breakfast sandwich). Used it for the first time this morning. It heated quickly and evenly comparable to a non-stick pan of similar size. For reference, I cook my eggs over hard. I used butter as a grease/fat and though there was some egg stuck to the bottom when I flipped it despite the good coating of butter, I think I only need to cook it at a slightly slower and lower setting to avoid that the next time. Even so, the egg was easy to flip with a small rubber spatula.
title: Great fried egg in this one-egg pan!

author: Cody
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2021
review_content: I swear I'm cooking more because of this pan. It's the perfect size to make: a couple perfect fried eggs, a grilled cheese sandwich (or two, depending on the size of the bread), the perfect veggie stir fry, or anything else you might want. For me, it's not too small or too big; easy to pick up and move around. Very easy to clean & season. Handles stay fairly cool & I love, love, love the extra "assist handle" opposite the main long handle, which doesn't come on many pans. I also bought a tempered glass lid and so I can use it to steam veggies in the pan (helpful with tricky stir fry like the delicious one I made with brussel sprout shavings, which can be tough to cook). I'm so happy with this pan!
title: Should have bought this sooner

author: Charlie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2021
review_content: I love this skillet! If you are new cast iron owner Lodge is the best on the market! I have owned several other cast iron pans but Lodge is the brand I always buy.Lodge is preseason but I always season cast iron before first use. I used it to sear chicken then finished by covering with foil and baking. The meat seared evenly and baked perfectly without sticking. I have used to bake rolls, cornbread, breakfast casseroles and desserts. Consistent, even heat/baking. Clean up was simple.The only drawback is that it doesn't have a lid. It would be incredible if the lid were a little griddle.
title: Nice skillet. GREAT value! LODGE is BEST!

author: Bill Harberts
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2019
review_content: Nothing made of cast iron heats evenly, and you do have to be careful when you clean and dry cast iron cookware.  That said, I oiled and baked mine a few times when I first got it, and now it is virtually non-stick.  There is nothing like cast iron for baking cornbread and I can sear anything in it beautifully once it heats up.  I prefer it to a non-stick skillet for bacon and eggs in the morning, it will sear pork chops beautifully, deglazes easily to make a great pan sauce, and it usually wipes clean with just a damp cloth.  I put it back on a burner or in the still warm oven after washing it to be sure it is dry and it stays in great shape.  It is the most versatile skillet I own.  You just need to work with the quirks that go with using cast iron.
title: It is the most useful skillet I own.

author: Rob
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2019
review_content: I had a decent non-stick pan I used primarily for eggs. It was great for a few years but then, like all non-stick, it start sticking.This time around I decided to replace it with a cast iron and Lodge was the only manufacturer I even considered. I have several (six or seven) various cast iron pieces from Lodge - there are other US-based manufacturers who make some really nice looking pieces but there simply isn't anything on the market that beats Lodge in terms of quality. ANd Lodge is really well priced, so this was a no-brainer purchase.I have learned, though, that all cast iron pieces need to be seasoned before use. Yes, Lodge pieces are pre-seasoned but they perform much better if you season them again prior to their first use. Don't remove the seasoning that it comes with, just do another layer on top.Definitely nice have a small but very versatile pan in the kitchen - I use it on the stove, the grill, and even on a portable induction burner,
title: Needed to Replace my Egg Pan

author: ATL_Prime_Shopper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2017
review_content: I've had a few Lodge cast iron items from Dutch ovens to grill pans but for some reason I never had a good skillet. So I bought this one. (A few days later I found the same one at Home Goods for 3 bucks less..argh!)I had never bought a pre-seasoned item before though. So I was pleasantly surprised that the factory seasoning was decent. It wasn't years of seasoning right out of the box but it got you started. I made some skillet potatoes in it the first weekend I had it. They did stick a bit more than I expected but not horrible. I made a few other dishes and then decided to season it myself to see if it made a huge difference. It did. I seasoned it as I usually do with my cast iron and this thing it's awesome. So all in all, you can use it out of the box but you'll be happier if you season it yourself.
title: ... pans but for some reason I never had a good skillet. So I bought this one

author: Holden Caulfield
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2020
review_content: As soon as this skillet arrived, I took it out to my shop and smoothed it out w/a random orbital sander, inside and out -- the rough handle, too.Then, I wore out a couple of super heavy duty abrasive pads, scrubbing it, mercilessly, in hot soapy water, then ice cold water, then sponging it, then drying with a towel, then on the stove.After seasoning it a few times, it is as smooth as a baby's bottom and food slides around on it like it does on my 100 year old Vollrath #9 skillet!  I don't doubt, someone will be cooking up great meals in this new masterpiece, 100 years from now.And that, along with avoiding all the negative consequences of throw-away teflon pans, is why I now use cast iron skillets and ovens more than anything else.  An American made skillet that cost less than $15, that cooks this well and could last forever is something to shout about!!
title: Hope to Shout!!  It's that good!!!

author: JC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2021
review_content: I bought this skillet to use outdoors b/c it’s cheap. I have a lodge dutch oven for that reason too. I’ve never been a fan of the textured cooking surface of Lodge. I’m still not, but the good vintage stuff is expensive. Lodge cast iron won’t keep a season and is hard to clean. I have cast iron that was my Grandma’s. Smooth as glass surface. With proper care nothing sticks to it and it will last many generations. People who aren’t familiar with the care and how to use cast iron won’t know what they’re missing by using Lodge.
title: Not a fan of Lodge

author: Frozen Northlander
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2020
review_content: I have several Lodge skillets as well as two Griswold skillets from the 19th century.  The Lodge products seem to have gone a bit downhill in quality over the years.  They do not season properly as my older Lodge skillets did.  In addition, the heat distribution of the 8" pan is rather uneven.  I have replaced that pan with a 8"French Chasseur Pan that is more than perfect.  Eggs actually do slide out perfectly (it looks like a tv commercial!).  It is a bit expensive at $113.00, but after spending a lot of money searching for a good pan, I am very happy.  I have purchased one of the expensive pans for each daughter.
title: Not what is expected from Lodge.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2019
review_content: Always wanted to try cast iron skillets so I got the 8 inch. You can pretty much do everything with it and it will last a lifetime as long as you treat it right. The first couple uses are better if you cook food with higher fat content like meats and such. After a couple uses I started doing eggs and pancakes in it flawlessly. To clean mine, I do the following while the pan is still hot, combine kosher salt with a little oil and scrub hard with a sponge or rag. Rinse and dry it, then put a little oil to spread all over. Place it over the stove until you see smoking. Then remove it, cool down, and you're ready to go for next time! The quality of this pan is amazing and USA made. Can't ask for more than that! The flavors of foods really come alive cooking with this and distributes heat evenly.
title: So in love with this little gem!

author: Millian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2020
review_content: I love cast iron (as well as stainless steel) and I’ve finally tossed all of my Teflon aluminum non-stick pans. I trust Lodge stuff. Yes, these new lodge pans have a sandpaper like cooking surface (unlike smooth old milled out Wagner/Grissy) but that doesn’t mean they can’t be non-stick. I bought this new lodge last week and it is already non-stick. I fried eggs and made Swedish pancakes in it yesterday. The trick is to season the thing properly and cook at medium temperatures. I don’t trust the lodge pre-seasoning because it’s filmy and leaves residue. So I remove it using my ovens self clean process, then I wash the pan with soap, dry it, heat it, then start the seasoning process with cooking oils. 200 degrees then oil, wipe off, 450 degrees (or above whatever your oils smoke point is) for one hour, let cool, repeat and cook on medium heat. Hot pan cold oil.If you must have a smooth surface because you don’t like the scraping sound from your spatula touching the lodge, then there’s always that stripping pad and 5 inch stick-on sanding pads for your drill... less than 20 minutes of work and your lodge will be smooth as a baby’s boo boo.I have Wagner/Griswold old pans and the Lodge, at $8 to $25 on sale, is so worth it. The lodge can be non-stick and smooth at fraction of price with no wobble or spinning.
title: Don’t believe the smooth/shiny hype...
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: dyiguy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2019
review_content: I added to my existing three piece collection with 8", 10.25", and  13.25' skillets.Cast iron skillets are not for beginner cooks. Stick-free pans are a no-brainer; put in some olive oil and cook.Cast iron requires some skill and attention. You have to maintain a seasoned, oiled pan; you must preheat; and you must know how to cook your food. With a non-stick pan, you throw in the food, play with the heat all you want and out it comes. Not so with cast iron. For eggs, you need just the right temp, not too cold and not too hot. Too cold and your eggs with stick as they eventually cook. Too hot and they will stick when they hit. Not hard to do if you know what you're doing.Ditto large skillets and other foods like breaded chicken cutlets and meatballs where you want some browning and want the brown bits to stay on your food.Best practice is to use these skillets a lot so they build up a good oily seasoned skin.They are much heavier than non-stick so not for old folks with wrist and elbow issues. You need a pad in the sink to wash otherwise you will scuff up the sink, especially white sinks. You cannot hold the large skillet and wash with the other hand.Definitely buy the rubber pot handles. The handles get too hot to use when cooking. Get two or three if you do major cooking with multiple skillets going.Also buy stock in a vegetable oil company. You will be using lots more to season the skillets. Lots more.
title: Great for eggs

author: KDDenn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2020
review_content: I've been cooking on a 10" skillet but needed a bigger one. I've used the heck out of this since getting it a month ago. Even used it on a 2 burner Coleman camping stove. This thing is awesome. Cleans up very easily. If there was any complaint, it would be that it is very heavy! Don't plan on using one hand to lift off the stove, especially with food in it. I got the silicon handle guard which I recommend also, but you will still have to grab both sides of the skillet to move it. But hey, its a skillet, its supposed to be heavy.Saw a few reviews where people complain about cleaning....well, its a skillet. You have to know how to properly clean it. Some people complained it cracked, but I used that 2 burner Coleman camp stove which was very uneven heating and no issues.Oh, did I mention it was heavy?
title: Love cooking on this!

author: crunchylicenseplates
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2020
review_content: My wife bought me a 15" Iron Skillet to take with me when I do BSA campouts with my son. I do the cooking for the adults. Yes the adults camp separate from the kids. They have to cook their own stuff, but the adults eat very well. I take this thing and it's enormous, it helps make the biggest cinnamon rolls, 2 packs of bacon, or a mountain man breakfast that is out of this world. Of course seasoning it right and taking care of it is key. Cooking bacon in it, then cooking burgers with butter on the patties will make anyone heart stop (except a 12 yo).  The stove we have isn't quite big enough to handle this thing, but cooking on an open fire is AWESOME! Can't wait to do more. The Amazon rating had something to do with cleaning, we all know that you just wipe these things down, if you clean it, you're doing something wrong. Do your homework before you buy something like this. Look up "Steel Skillet Seasoning". They are heavy, just so you know. Could be used as a home defense weapon, LOL!
title: The One To Get for BSA Adult Camp Outs

author: Kimjoda
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2020
review_content: It’s a nice-sized pan and the opposing side helper handle is sufficient enough so as to mitigate the weight of the pan.  The weight is what kept me from buying one sooner.  The care and cleaning of the pan seem to be manageable for the ability to finally cook a steak well.  The product arrived safely which is ONLY due to the sturdiness/durability of the pan.  It was unwrapped, moving around inside a much larger box.  The box was damaged and the delivery person gave me the option of rejecting it.  Though it wasn’t totally opened at the point, I thought I’d take a risk and accept it....and then return it if necessary.  WHAT a POOR packing job this was.  It wasn’t even wrapped in paper within the box.  The packers need to up their game.
title: Finally caved....so I could sear steaks...

author: mmz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2020
