review_content: When this Lodge product arrived with a chip, it is hard to give it anything but a one star. It did arrive so one star. I added a photo and it may not seem like a lot but when cast iron has this flaw we all know that nothing but rust follows it, no matter how well oiled it is kept. I’m also going to knock Amazon because a 10” skillet came in a 21x 15x 6 box with no covering, no packing peanuts, plastic or even brown paper! Just a skillet in a huge box. I can’t rate the other items for star ratings because I haven’t used the product and I’m thinking about sending it back. If I’m forced to rate it because it won’t accept submit I will give it one star for not being able to bypass.
title: A Chip is Not Acceptable

author: Plains
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2020
review_content: Honestly we cook on the same surface multiple times a day for years it really matters what you cook on. I’m a minimalist in the sense that if I can get one or two things instead of ten I’ll prefer that. To me this cast iron skillet handles that. I’m just appreciative for the great value that is this product. It’s a really good price for what it is. I used to use cheap non stick pans but then did my research and learned about all the horrible chemicals that leech off those. And don’t read their advertising because they pretend like they’re safe but they’re not. Cast iron is safe though.
title: Wish I switched to this sooner
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: J Mac
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2020
review_content: My wife dumped me a while back-thank god! Now I only have to cook for me. No more having to listen the constant “you burnt it, this tastes terrible, you call yourself a cook” all that business. Sheesh- it’s amazing I still have enamel on my teeth after trying to choke down her lemon juice salad dressing on that blank blank raw Kale. So now I only have to cook for me and this little 8” number is just spot on. From Dutch Babies to Filet Mignon to seared scallops and Lobster Thermidor, it does it all! Glad I didn’t have it when I was married or old “Slackjaw” might’ve tried to stick around a bit longer.
title: Great buy now that I am cooking for  one.

author: MZ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2019
review_content: I purchased the Lodge L8SK3 10-1/4-Inch Pre-Seasoned Skillet.As I have no experience with other brands of cast iron pan this review is based on my satisfaction with this pan having met and exceeded my expectations, not comparison with other cast iron pans.Pros:*  Food doesn't stick. It's not quite a non-stick surface, but I am surprised at how close it comes.*  Holds heat well so I'm getting an excellent sear on the food I've cooked sous vide.*  Can be heated plenty hot without damage to it's surface - unlike my non-stick cookware.*  After two years of use its non stick properties only seem if anything to be improving.*  Extremely happy with the price (less than $15 for a pan that I'm expecting to last years!)Cons*  I think clean up needs to be done asap for cast iron so I don't have the option to be lazy and wait a day!*  Cleanup is more involved than just tossing in the dishwasher or scrubbing and leaving out to dry.I purchased the "Lodge L8SK3 10-1/4-Inch Pre-Seasoned Skillet" in January of 2018 to use for searing items after having cooked them sous vide. I had not previously used cast iron pans, but using this one has been a pleasure.I usually use this pan on a portable induction burner, but I also use it occasionally on our stove top and it works fine there as well. After each use I scrub the cooking surface with kosher salt, rinse, wash with dish soap and water, dry, lightly rub with avocado oil, and place on a hot burner to ensure every bit of moisture has evaporated. This is all actually pretty quick and easy, but it's definitely more effort than "wash and wipe", and I make a point of doing it as soon after use as I can. After two years of use my pan is still perfect shape. I plan to continue following this procedure, but my review would not be an honest one without mentioning how I have used and maintained this pan.
title: I've been using this 10.25 inch pan for almost two years now and I'm very happy with it!

author: Wanat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2021
review_content: I've got a mix of lodge and old Wagner. My two most recent purchases are the lodge wok 14" I believe, which I've had for 7years, and this 15" skillet. I can cook 3 lbs of potatoes, 2lbs of onions, and 1lb of sausage into a "hash" with enough room. It cleans easy after a few cooks, but I was fairly impressed with the factory seasoning. Obviously it's not the same casting as 40-50 year old Wagner, but whatever. For anyone looking for a metal lid for this, the following is a perfect fit for this and the wok:Update International SPC-140 Stainless Steel Stock Pot Cover, 32-Quart, Silver
title: Awesome for the price

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2021
review_content: Great for making a couple of eggs in the morning. I often cook only for one or occasionally two. This is the perfect size for that. Especially if you dread cleaning pots and pans and dishes like me.

review_content: Honestly, this is a good pan and I got it at a great price. The reason I won't give it the full 5 stars is because this did not come properly preseasoned. Food stuck to the bottom and the sides so I will have to season it myself.

author: Livingandlearning
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2018
review_content: This little skillet is the right size to cook the foods that keep me healthy - and prepared for a zombie should one appear at my campsite. The edges that pour are a plus. I have lightweight camping gear but have been missing real cooking during my overnight camping. I was missing my cast iron skillet.This is the right size skillet to cook whatever I want. It’s heavy so I have to trade off on other gear. I decided to order a lightweight air sleeping pad from Amazon. Sleep is also important to me. Good food, good sleep, protection from chiggers, ants, mosquitoes, bears, raccoons, the cold, the sun, and zombies are important to me for a great camping experience.I am currently experiencing 50 plus chigger bites because I did not think chiggers were in the part of the country I was hiking this Season. I thought wrong(ly.)From now on, I hike using lightweight gear - but I will be comfortable. Using a small cast iron skillet won’t kill chiggers but at least I can cook a pleasant meal instead of suffering with bites and a protein bar. I will be cooking numerous recipes at home and at camp with this little skillet. I chose this 6 1/2” size because I can cook both meat and eggs in it side by side.I can rehydrate veggies and make an omelette. I can cook pineapple upside down cake. The list goes on.The thin lightweight cooking gear is great for boiling water but this cast iron skillet can do it all. I hope you found this review helpful as you decide which gear is right for your situation. I hope you found this review helpful and a little bit humorous. Sometimes the truth is the funniest. A little humor relieves the boredom of online shopping.
title: The right size for camping for one - maybe two

author: Ben
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
review_content: but it has proven quite challenging to clean, and the time it takes to build up a nice layer of seasoning which can make it non-stick is taking months and months of consistent use and painstaking cleaning (this is standard for most skillets, but especially here because of the so-so job Lodge did at providing a pre-season).I recommend skillet cooking to everyone, but keep in mind it takes a tremendous amount of effort to maintain (tremendous compared to other types of pans / cook trays).It makes superb steaks though. If you don't have an open-flame grill, skillets are the way to go. Meats, veggies, cakes, cookies, anything under the sun will taste exquisitely non-metallic with a good, well-seasoned skillet.

author: Richard A. Silcox
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2021
review_content: This is a great pan to get if you're interested in learning to cook with cast iron. The pan is pre-seasoned to it is ready to go right out of the box. The 10" size is small but good for learning basic cooking and cleaning of cast iron. The price is really good for this as well. I eventually got a 12" pan for larger meals but I still use this one to cook for myself.  DO please remember to use proper maintenance on the pan. author: JMShamberg
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2019
review_content: I am no passionate cast iron enthusiast, who knows the nuisances between different brands of cast iron. However, in my neck of the woods Lodge produces what would be considered the modern quintessential 10.25" cast iron pan. I find it in most cooking stores. Amazon just had the best price at the time. The product received was as anticipated.There are always going to be people recommending you thirft shop and restore an old one if you can. However, for ease of access and price. You are not going to go wrong. Just remember to always do some additional cleaning and seasoning prior to its first use. The standard online method usually take 45 min-2 hours depending on repetition.if you want to know more, the internet has many more educated people than myself to tell you all about it.
title: It's a Lodge Cart Iron Skillet

author: Illustrious
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2019
review_content: I got this for under $15.  I already knew how to cook with a cast iron, and I was staying in a place where all the pots and pans were nonstick(which are less nonstick than cast iron) and stainless steel(which are extremely difficult to stop things from sticking to).  I'm sure all of those other pans cost them more than this cast iron pan cost me, and I use this one almost exclusively for both stovetop and oven use for 3 months now.  I've even done a few cakes and pies and they came out easily.  I ignore whenever a recipe tells me to use parchment paper and use the cast iron pan instead.  Works.  Every.  Time.  The one thing that will kind of stick to it is if you cook cheese in it too much, but even that is easy to clean with a stainless steel scrubby.  If it's your first cast iron, just look up how to take care of them and you'll be fine.
title: Great Value for the Money!

author: LTJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2020
review_content: I have to say, this may be one of the best pans I’ve ever used. My father-in-law told me for months how much he loved his pan, so I finally decided to purchase it in 15”. I’ve cooked everything NB g under the moon in it and I absolutely love it. Cleaning it is a little different, but the more I use it the better the flavor is. I just try not to wash it with soap, and if I have to scrub it at all I “season” it back with a little bit of vegetable oil afterwards. Joked with my wife this evening that, alone, I could survive the rest of my life with just this pan. Be advised, this pot (15”) requires to hands to pickup and hold. A slightly smaller size would be perfect for one hand and smaller meals.
title: You can cook anything in this pan!

author: Spuds
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2019
review_content: I'm thinking it will take some time to get a world-class seasoning on this. The price makes it a very good value.Solid, heavy construction. I ran steel wool over it to smooth out the rough pre-seasoning as much as I could stand and ran it thru 4 seasoning cycles. Cooked bacon and eggs - one of my guests was making happy noises as she ate. I think that clearly says enough. Cleaned up easily.The concern  - somehow mine had no damage from shipping - no dents, cracks or anything - real nice. They must have taken great care handling this. It shipped in an overly large box with no padding. Well, one token piece of packing paper was thrown in.
title: Not Bad at All!
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Count Orloff
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2015
review_content: We've gone through a few grills in anodize aluminum, they get really stick-prone after a few years. Stainless steel is just awful for frying and incredibly hard to clean. Teflon wears out. Cast iron is where it's at. I mean for stock pots and sauce pans stainless is probably better. But for frying and grilling, CAST IRON! After using it for a few weeks the seasoning on this is pretty good. I have read that super smooth cast iron is better, and we have a really old smooth 13" Wagner classic iron frypan up at our shared mountain cabin. (The really sought after kind.) I think the Wagner is about perfect, but this new Lodge pan is actually pretty darn good. I have recently come to appreciate cast iron, what I really notice is that you can truly brown meat and even veggies really quickly, whereas stainless and aluminum it take far longer and just doesn't get as brown and crispy. Also fried hash browns are actually very crispy in a cast iron pan, whereas is stainless or aluminum they just aren't. We've done eggs and fritatas and Dutch Babies in the pan and they don't stick much at all.  At the price this is just a steal. I would say everyone needs one of these pans, they are just awesome. And will last a number of lifetimes.
title: Now THIS is a frypan

author: Anonymous

review_content: Didn't come in a fancy package, but this is the pan!  After returning a couple of other purchases of products made in China, finally found the best pan.  No cadmium.  No black paint.  This has been made in Tennessee, USA since the 1800's.  Family owned and operated.  Quality shows.  So happy I finally found this  The surface is slightly rough because of the sanding process they use for the seasoning to adhere.  This will get even better with age.  If you want a quality, genuine, cast iron skillet at a reasonable price, buy Lodge!
title: This is the pan!

author: Lacrocivious Acrophosist
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2018
review_content: You know on the cooking shows where the chefs toss the contents of the pan in the air instead of stirring? If you can do that with this pan, I don't want to get in a fight with you ;-)The 12-inch cast iron Lodge pan is *heavy*. But that is a good thing. It heats up evenly and holds heat well, and provides plenty of real estate for whatever you're cooking in it. The silicone grip is a nice extra. As with all pre-seasoned cast iron, the factory seasoning isn't all that great, but it does allow you to begin using it immediately. For a really good finish you will definitely want to do your own seasoning, possibly several times for a robust cooking surface.
title: Build up your wrist strength!

author: applecorrie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2019
review_content: First let me say that I've been struggling to get my eggs out of a ceramic skillet without them stick to the pan (unless I used an obscene amount of oil)!  I was finally fed up so I decided to replace my old skillet with a cast iron skillet from Lodge.  I am extremely pleased with my new skillet!  You do have to let cast iron warm up before you add oil or whatever you are cooking, but when I follow that procedure I get perfect eggs (that have little to know sticking) every time!  Then as soon as the food is done (while the pan is still hot) I run very hot tap water over the pan and give it a scrub either with my non scratch scrubbies, my stainless steel chain mail, or with a sturdy brush.  After its clean I dry it thoroughly, then I put it back on the stove on medium heat until the rim of the skillet is hot (this way it has time to dry completely) then I apply a thin layer of grapeseed oil all over the inside surface (I've been using a bandana to do the job) then I use a clean portion of the lint free cloth or some paper towels to remove any excess oil that was not absorbed by the pan (otherwise the surface will become sticky) then I just let the pan cool completely while it sits on the stove before I put it away.  If you need more hints and tips there are tons of people on youtube with really great care advice (I really like coyboykentrollins videos).
title: I'm in love!  Perfect Eggs!

author: crème.brûlée
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2018
review_content: I like that the pan came seasoned. However, I did end up seasoning the pan in the oven to add a few more layers.  It took me some time to figure out the correct temperature and preheating time for the pan when cooking different foods. The cooking surface gets better with more usage. I can now cook eggs and pancakes without them sticking to the pan. My favorite food to cook using this pan is steak. The steak develops a delicious crust while remaining tender and juicy on the inside. Burgers and pizza also taste delicious when cooked in this pan. Most of the time I only need to wipe out the pan with a paper towel in order to clean it. For times when that is not enough, I rub the inside of the pan with coarse salt to remove any food residue. On rare occasions, I will use a drop of mild dish soap with a soft sponge. I then rinse the pan with water and dry it with a dish cloth or paper towel. After that, I heat the pan on the stove for a couple of minutes and rub it with a very thin layer of oil. Once the pan starts smoking, I turn off the heat and let it cool down. I have not had any issues with the pan rusting by following the aforementioned steps.
title: Great for My First Cast Iron Pan

author: Michael L
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2021
review_content: Be careful when ordering cast iron on line, I ordered this piece and when it arrived LATE I unboxed it and looked it over and found when putting a straight edge on the bottom of the skillet there was a gap of 1/8"-3/16" and you could see the warp protruding up into the skillet like a small dome. This is not good for cast iron, all your food will burn in the middle as all the oils will pool on the edges of the skillet. Keep in mind to put a straight edge on the bottom to check for flatness. It seems people are buying seconds from the manufacturer and trying to flip them to unsuspecting buyers.
title: Lodge 12" cast iron skillet

author: Ari
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2020
review_content: What can I say? I am obsessed with this pan. I absolutely love it and I'm frustrated when I have forgotten to clean it right away because I can't immediately use it. I cook everything in this. Steak. Eggs. Veggies. Ragout. It's so versatile and I love being able to go from stovetop to oven without any real thought.Says it's pre-seasoned but that's a lie. No such thing as a pre-seasoned cast iron pan. I recommend using flax seed oil for a solid, shiny seasoning. It's really inexpensive at Walmart and I've barely used any of the bottle I bought despite having had this pan for months now (i bought it when I had a different pan I accidentally left behind at my old place of residence).I like that the other handle has finger loops, makes gripping it with a potholder much easier. I would still suggest getting a leather or silicone sleeve to cover the main handle for safety, just remember to remove it if you stick it in the oven.No complaints, this is a great product!
title: Amazing pan for an amazing price

author: NJBuyer2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2020
review_content: This 10.25" skillet is a welcome new addition to my kitchen pan collection.  As I always do, I will given it a couple of rounds of new seasoning before I use it, and as always I will clean it out correctly and dry it immediately to avoid the rust that so many people report.  Cast iron use and ownership has a learning curve, and many sources are out there to assist with that.  THAT BEING SAID, this skillet I received today had some sticky, stinky goo worked into the ridge on the underside.  When I wiped it with a paper towel, what I saw as a dull greenish-gray. Smells like soap or some sort of detergent. It must have been set down into some sort of spill prior to packaging, as the box itself has only a trace of the smell clinging to it and almost no goo.  Ugh.  Someone's return which was not properly vetted for resale???
title: Lodge cast iron never disappoints!  Amazon's shipping, though ...

author: The Fred
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2020
review_content: I've got three sizes of cast iron skillets; 8, 10 and 12 inch.  This little 8-incher I use the most.  Lodge cast iron comes pre-seasoned and is nearly non-stick as purchased.  I keep it that way by 1) never clean with soap and 2) season after each use.  To season, I add a few drops of olive oil and spread it around with a paper towel then wipe dry.  Heat the pan until the oil smokes and the oil coating stops shining, then leave it to cool.  This builds up a really good non-stick coating and sterilizes the pan
title: High quality and Made in America

author: ParkSD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2018
review_content: We use our toaster oven a lot to heat up and even bake things.  I love that I can put the skillet in the little oven and it is still big enough to put on my gas stove.  I own other cast iron including Lodge who makes most of their products in the USA.  I highly recommend this skillet for cooking/baking small portions. You can cook a couple of eggs in it, an English muffin, some ham and make a breakfast sandwich.  Bake a small pie or huge cookie.  Easy to clean up. I've never had any problems with the roughness of the Lodge skillets.  As I use it, the cast iron gets slicker and more non-stick.  And one more thing, a lot of negative reviews on Amazon for cast iron products are from people who seem like they aren't prepared to own a cast iron product.  If you have never owned cast iron, I would make sure that you understand how to take care of it properly.  I hate to see reviews where they say that they tossed it in the garbage when the skillet rusted.  Donate or give it away before you trash it.  A cast iron skillet will be snatched up at a thrift store.  What a waste.  As long at the skillet isn't broken or cracked, it can be cleaned, re-seasoned and put back into use.  A broken skillet can still be recycled where they take metal.  So prepare yourself before you buy.  There is tons of information and videos out there on how to care for cast iron.
title: Love that this skillet will fit in my toaster oven!

author: D. Eadie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2021
review_content: This is my first ever purchase of a cast iron pan, but I grew up cooking with my mother's vintage cast iron. Now, all of her's were made back in the day when the inside of cast iron cookware was polished smooth, and of course today that's not done except on some very expensive brands. Nonetheless, I cooked up a meal of shakshuka in this pan and there was no sticking, except a little bit of egg. (I did do a pre-seasoning in addition to the factory pre-seasoning.) So far I'm pleased, and while I hope to score some nice, smooth vintage cookware someday, I'm happy with this pan and will probably add a bigger skillet soon.
title: As expected, a great cast iron pan

author: Bri J
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2021
review_content: It came shipped in a box with very little packing, which caused it to be delivered with the handle physically sticking out of the box...It seems to be good quality. I have no clue what I'm talking about as far as the "seasoning", so I can't review that part of it. I think it will take a bit of time getting used to how much it heats up! And like all other cast iron skillets, the clean up process isn't super easy and the upkeep can seem tedious. But has been a great addition to our kitchen.Overall, I'm HAPPY WITH THE PURCHASE!
title: Great addition to any kitchen

author: D. W.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2020
review_content: LOVE IT! I knew little about cast iron, but read up on them before ordering. I did season mine, but Lodge does as well so it's probably not necessary. I admit to being afraid of a sticking mess, especially with omelettes and pancakes. But you know what... As long as you use a little oil or butter, it's as non-stick as you could imagine! Pancakes come out beautifully and don't stick AT ALL! I'm actually shocked, to be honest. What I love about it is it actually makes omlettes taste SIGNIFICANTLY better. Something about cast iron adds flavor. It's truly uncanny. Also, I love how freakin' tough this thing is. You can tell it will just last forever, unlike the crappy pans you see nowadays. Lodge is the epitome of quality. Don't think twice. Just order one!
title: FANTASTIC, tough as nails and non-stick!

author: Justin Sanford
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
review_content: Even after seasoning this pan it still had a little sticking. I had to cook some high fat foods on it for a while to really get it to where it needed to be. Needless to say it is quite non stick now. Heavy HEAVY pan. (obviously, cast iron). I'm very pleased with it, probably got it for 10 or so less dollars than I could have at my local chains. It actually pulls heat very quickly. Please don't put them in the dishwasher. Mine is regularly just hanging out with a coating of previous great on it, I'll give it a quick wipe down and every now and then take it to the sink and immediately dry it. It has been going strong and doing a great job for about 6 months now! I am very pleased with my purchase.
title: I would season it again just to be sure

author: Spagetti Bender
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2017
review_content: Why did I abandon my old cast irons for stainless steel, and no stick pots and pans? This Lodge cast iron skillet out preforms everything else I've owned over the years, and they were high quality brands (expensive too). Concerns for the no stick wearing off and contaminating our food motivated us to try the good old fashion cast iron. Glad we did. Better heat distribution, cooks foods evenly. A small amount of cooking oil keeps most things from sticking. The downside to cast iron cooking is having to season it with oil after washing. Also, be sure to use a pot holder or heat gloves, the handle gets awfully hot.The Lodge brand seems to be better made than others we have looked at. Finish is smoother. Lodge Manufacturing company is  the only major manufacturer of cast-iron cookware in the United States. The other cookware suppliers use pots and pans made in Asia or Europe. They tend to be courser in finish.
title: Back to basics in cookware.

author: Jay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2019
review_content: I had also purchased 2 other larger Skillets by a different brand than Lodge (OCXA? something). I seasoned all three in the very same manner & also as recommended by the Mfg.  This LODGE Skillet has a much better surface texture, smoother, than the other two so doesn't grab whatever you're cooking.  The other brand not only grabbed an egg I tried to fry, it left a ring mark after trying to clean it every which way even after using the metal chain scrub.  ?  I sent back the other 2 & will replace them with the Lodge or keep searching the Tag Sales for 2 Vintage ones.I've been using it frequently for quick sauté's of onions, shallots, etc for my Burgers and smaller portions like eggs, ham, etc.  I leave it on my stovetop in the back as the black with the Red Silicone Handle looks great & very inviting.You definitely need the Silicone cover as the handle does get super hot but you also can cook on a much lower heat/flame setting.  It gives a nice heat distribution as well.This was a good value purchase & love my little Skillet!RECOMMEND.
title: Sweet & Handy Little Skillet !
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 8-InchVerified Purchase

author: Jen9999
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2017
review_content: This is a very large skillet. Because of that it is a challenge to handle when cleaning or storing. The bottom surface is more like a griddle because it is so large and flat. Because it's so large, it requires more oil and takes longer to heat up. Just a caveat if you are cooking for one or two people. It is a good size to cook three ribeye steaks, though.I've used it to cook fried eggs and oven-seared steaks.I love that this skillet is preseasoned. You DO NOT need to season this skillet when you first start to use it. If it needs seasoning later, just put a little oil and heat in a 500 degF oven until thoroughly heated. Wipe out and repeat as desired. The cooking surface may seem "rough" but, as other reviewers have noted, really the "peaks" keeps eggs from sticking as they would to a completely smooth surface. Lodge knows what they are doing.I DO clean it with a LITTLE dish soap, then dry on medium high heat for a few minutes. When cool, I wipe olive or vegetable oil on a paper towel throughout the interior.One caveat -- it is very large and heavy. You will need the silicone hot handle holders for both handles to safely remove it from the oven. (You slip them on as you go to lift the skillet from the oven.)  The 15" skillet did NOT fit in my small apartment oven, so I use it at my other house.
title: Great Cast Iron Skillet -- Very Large!

author: Nightflyer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2020
review_content: This is my second purchase. Bought this one for my granddaughter as a housewarming present. I reseasoned mine when I got it, and advised her to do the same. I like buying made in America, and I know Lodge from the "good old days". I had my mother's cast iron, which was literally as smooth as a baby's bottom from the getgo. Nowadays, all the cast iron, except the most expensive, has a rough interior. I find I need to reseason every few months to keep it truly non-stick. Oh, for the "egg skillet" that only cooked eggs & was almost like a teflon skillet, so smooth & non-stick. Perhaps my granddaughter's will get that smooth with wear. I would buy this again, and may do so as it's a great present, especially for young people building their home goods.
title: Lodge Quality

author: TK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2019
review_content: You can't go wrong with Lodge. I see a lot of comments about people getting upset about rust, but honestly I think a lot of that comes from not knowing how to properly care for cast iron. I know people get huffy and say they know what they are doing, but they usually don't. This little pan is awesome. We did a skillet cookie and it cooked evenly and perfectly. I seasoned it when it first came and have used it several times since, it it still has a beautiful black sheen. Don't bother buying cast iron if you are not going to do the research of properly caring for it.
title: Excellent pan.

author: AwwD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2019
review_content: This is my first cast iron product and well, I screwed up the first seasoning and even screwed up undoing my screw up I think. But! Even with that in mind I think over time this pan has gotten better as I’ve applied the seasoning more and have been working diligently to ensure this skillet is maintained. With that, I’ve made so many good foods with this thing that I’ve been using it more than my nonstick even at times where the nonstick might have made more sense. But cooking with this is so nice and the flavors of what comes out of this are great. Steaks, eggs, vegetables, potatoes...if you treat this tool well, it’ll treat you well. I think this is a required cooking utensil for any kitchen
title: Great skillet

author: chw
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2020
review_content: This is a key pan for home cooking. Core cook wear is stainless but over the last 3+ months the need for cast iron became obvious. This pan is made in the USA by a long term manufacturer and is an exceptional buy at the Amazon price point. Caution is required in use and emphasized by the manufacturer for electric induction flat top stoves. It heats well, note the handle heats up as well, and holds the temp. Great utility for going from stove top to oven in cooking as well as direct baking. Recommend d/l mfg guidance from the Net on use and maintenance. Re-seasoned before first use. Clean up 4 out of 5 depending on use. Use hot water and stiff brush for cleaning after use with oil wipe.
title: Critical Kitchen Tool

author: Eric Rybarczyk
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review_content: I love it for the simple fact my roommates wont use it since they dont know how to properly clean it, although they have a habit of leaving their dirty pans after the cook for a few days at a time. So it's nice to be able to come home from a long day at work and know that I can cook without having to clean dirty pans. As far as cleaning goes, some steel wool with water is all you need and then put in the oven or over heat to dry it out so it doesn't rust. If you use soap you risk messing up your oil seasoning of the pan which is the purpose of cast iron in my option is that pre-seasoning and developing flavour as you use it over time!
title: I love cast iron, only way I cook anymore...

author: SunEngine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2019
review_content: I am new to using Cast Iron, and was quite honestly a little scared of it.  I got the Lodge care kit as well so I would have the tools to keep it clean and seasoned.  Honestly I use this pan almost every day and it's getting better the more I use it.  I did not want "stuff" chipping off non-stick pans with coatings anymore.  Cast Iron is healthier, conducts heat better, and is really naturally nonstick if you take the small amount of care it needs.I am cooking all my proteins in this pan now, and am thrilled with how evenly it holds the heat and cooks.I love that Lodge is made in the US.  They are a very high quality product and I would not hesitate to recommend them to anyone.
title: Love Cast Iron!  This is a great value for a pre-seasoned pan.

author: StormyDays
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2021
review_content: I like Lodge Cast Iron Cookware. So I was mystified when I opened box to find it in this condition as depicted in the pictures. And the broken missing piece was NOT found in the box. The box did not show any damage. The other cast iron cookware in the box were in good shape. I am sure this is a fluke. I'm sending the skillet back for a refund. I would exchange or replace it, but I haven't the time to wait for shipment. Time is of essence.
title: Arrived with a large chunk missing

author: kbwarrior2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
review_content: I love this skillet!  I have gone from one cheap skillet to the next and they all have warped over my gas stove.  This the first time I've been able to cook evenly in a long time.  I like its sturdiness (it's almost TOO heavy for me to pick up and scrub, but I have always wanted an iron skillet and am very happy with it.  The one thing I should have done was get the suggested "potholders" that fit the handle and the opposite "lip".  I cannot pick it up to scrape food out of it, but I just spoon it out.  I also need a lid.  Overall, a great skillet!
title: Love this Skillet!

author: Heather S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2019
review_content: I have always wanted a cast iron pan. For several reasons but I mostly wanted it for the non-stick capabilities that I had heard about. First thing I cooked was an egg... stuck to the pan. I jumped on line and watched at least 5 videos about seasoning the pan (this Lodge came pre-seasoned). I followed their directions on how to season the pan...Basically, heat the pan (medium heat) on the top burner, while preheating the oven to 350. Spread a light coat of high temp oil (vegetable oil) evenly on the pan and then put it in the oven for an hour. LEAVE THE PAN IN THE OVEN UNTIL IT COOLS. I tried an egg again. NOPE still sticks. I became so frustrated with the pan that I "seasoned" the pan four more times using same method.... it still sticks. I don't know what to do and I have almost lost hope in the pans non-stick capability. Oh and its a pain in the rump to clean also. Im very disappointed.The only thumbs up I can give the pan is for its heat disbursement because it does a stellar job at that... and only that.
title: 1st ever cast iron pan

author: Aineadele
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2017
review_content: I love this pan SO much. It's absolutely beautiful. I'm transitioning to all nontoxic items in the kitchen, so I chose cast iron because it's so safe. There is a learning curve with cast iron. It has to be seasoned-which means you coat it with a healthy oil and buildup a layer of protective coating to prevent sticking. You can bake it in the oven between coats if you want to. It's perfectly fine to just wash this with a little soap and water, dry it, and re season it when it arrives. I've made eggs, rice, veggies, meat and casseroles in it so far. Things will stick at times-it just depends on the seasoning. It will take some getting used to, but it's worth it. Seasoning and caring for the pan is simple, but does take effort and patience. Once you're accustomed to it, it's easy. The food tastes great, and I love the peace of mind of it being a healthy cookware item.Just a heads up: okra turns black in cast iron (it looks weird, and you won't want to eat it), and cooking acidic foods like tomatoes will leach more iron than usual into the food and it might taste more metalic, unless really well seasoned. Some iron is ok for our diets, but not too much.
title: Love it!

author: Matt Li
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2019
review_content: Bought this as a test of cast iron pans. Was really amazed at how hot this pan gets and how it retains the heat. Brought this on my first camping trip and was perfect for over camp fire or on a propane stove. I love cooking bacon and steak on this pan compared to my other nonstick pans. When camping I used a crumbled up piece of aluminum foil to use to scrub this with salt. This pan is so hot that it just burns everything to crisp and then just scrubs off easily. What was annoying that I was not used to is the fact that I had to make sure to heat the pan after cleaning every time to make sure all the water evaporated to prevent from rusting. After doing this often, it's a good habit to clean the pan after cooking instead of letting it sit anyways. Most times at home, I don't even rinse the pan. I just scrub the food scraps off and leave it to use the next day.
title: HEAVY, HOT and makes amazing steak.

author: D. J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2021
review_content: Lodge is kind of the McCast Iron brand. I find their items to be pretty basic, but when you're dealing with cast iron, that's not a bad thing. After going through plenty of small "non-stick" skillets, especially for cooking eggs, I was getting frustrated with how much the eggs actually stuck. Now, I have been using a 10-inch cast iron skillet for some time, and after years of cooking and seasoning, I love how it treats food. So, I decided to get a mini skillet specifically for eggs. This pan already came seasoned, but I seasoned it more with some avocado oil, then dropped in plenty of butter, and fried up an egg. While not perfectly non-stick yet, there was minimal damage to the egg, and cleanup was paper-towel easy. I expect the coating to get better as it gets use, and have no regrets with my purchase. Hope this helps!
title: Straight-forward, no-nonsense little skillet.

author: silly goose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2021
review_content: This is a good starter skillet if you don't own one already. Heat distribution seems fine, although I'm definitely no expert. It's also much heavier than it looks at least when just holding it by the handle. It's advertised to be 5 lbs, which doesn't seem like much, but it's not something easily maneuvered by the handle itself if you don't have good arm strength. I weighed it and it does indeed only way 5 lbs 3.4oz. If you grab it by the handle and assist handle, then it's not bad at all. My only real complaint is that the handle is so damn small. It's like they made this for a ten year old.
title: Nice first cast iron skillet

author: JustinC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2021
review_content: Lodge Cast Irons are hands down the best on the market. Even though they say they are already seasoned, I highly recommend you season your cast-iron yourself before using it. Do not allow soapy water to sit in it for an extended period of time or it WILL strip the seasoning and will rust your pan. If you have remains on the pan that you cannot remove without soaking I highly recommend you wash with hot soapy water and scrape it off with a dense piece of plastic. It will come off that way. Make sure you rinse thoroughly with HOT water and re-season after so many uses.
title: Must season first.

author: Khang
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2021
review_content: Super heavy duty cast iron pan, what more can I say. It is an inexpensive purchase but a must have in your kitchen when cooking any large proteins or even baking various dishes from appetizers to desserts. I have used it for steaks and love the beautiful browning you get from this pan, and after I can throw in some rice for a fantastic fried rice with the remaining heat! You can even serve meals on this pan and it presents very well. Overall it is a great buy but does take time to get used to when heating and cleaning.
title: What a fantastic pan, a must have in the kitchen
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: Anonymous
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2019
review_content: Turned 50 this year and have resisted cast iron ever since cooking as being "hard to clean" or "high maintenance" and heavy.  Well, took the leap of faith and this is MY GO TO PAN!  I use it for everything, eggs, bacon, chicken, steak, pasta sauce, cornbread, etc.  EASY clean up if you follow the directions and heat and season the pan with oil after each use.  DO NOT use soap, just hot water to clean and the black and red scraping silicone tools.  I can't believe I waited this long before investing in a cast iron skillet.  You won't be disappointed!  (It is - by nature - heavier, of course.  But I also purchased the silicone handle cover and just use both hands to lift.)  FYI - my other pans are All Clad, but I use this single skilled over them now:)
title: My go to pan for everything!  Must buy.  Got the 10"

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2017
review_content: Lodge makes probably some of the best pans that you can use in the kitchen, or at the campsite, or to fend off would-be attackers.When treated correctly cast iron will out last you and your kids (and their kids, and their kids and... you get the idea). Once this pan gets hot it stays hot. You could easily sear off a few steaks in this skillet, or gently fry an egg for a velvety texture. Need to go from the stove to the oven? Go for, this pan won't care. Oh crap, the power's out? Throw it on the grill. I can't recommend Lodge cast iron enough. Buy it once and never buy it again.Remember cast iron is not great for high acid foods (think tomato or wine based sauces) for at least a while. Also they aren't the best for boiling water. I'm not deducting any stars for this because that is the nature of cast iron and will eventually go away with enough use.
title: Lodge makes probably some of the best pans that you can use in the kitchen

author: Bradley H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2020
review_content: I was always afraid of cooking with cast iron until I finally broke down and bought this pan.  I use this for everything.  If you take care of it and use it correctly nothing sticks.  Just wash with water and scrub brush after every use and apply thin layer of oil with a paper towel and it's ready for the next use.
title: Awesome

author: Kerin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2020
review_content: I didn't buy cast iron cookware as I had concerns of difficulty of maintaining them. Boy was I wrong! There are definitely some basic things you need to do (don't let it sit in water too long, or cook acidic food, etc), but once you have a good base coat of oil, you just need to be consistent with your cleaning and application of oils at each use.Don't let fear hold you back, get rid of your rubbish non-stick pans and explore the wonder of cooking with Cast Iron!!
title: An American Classic - great introduction to cast iron cooking

author: Thatchels
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2021
review_content: Everything about this cast iron is amazing! It’s super easy to clean and my food is better than ever! I love not using Teflon and heat sensitive pots. We use my lodge at home and recently took it camping. I recommend getting the silicone handle cover. It’s heavier than other pots because it’s cast iron but great quality!It’s easy to season and can take some rough traveling! I prefer my cast iron for cooking because it’s so easy to clean and can be used in so many ways! Combined with a blender and instant pot, I don’t need more dishes piling up in my cabinets for no reason.I have used it for frying fish, cooking eggs, curry, sautéing veggies, campfire nachos, and a skillet chocolate chip cookie which looked like a fancy dessert from a restaurant (vs small cookies for snacks). It went great with vanilla ice cream!Also the price was great! The same size and brand at a store in town cost twice as much!!!!
title: Let’s gather ‘round the campfire and sing...

author: Charlie in NW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2016
review_content: Quality and durability you can expect from Lodge.  As a mid-line, no frill, non-fancy-work-horse case iron product maker, Lodge does it very well.  If you are looking for a solid cast iron without all the bells and whistles and you are going for best bottom line (dollar wise), Lodge is the way to go.  This is not your enamel cast iron.  This is not your French ferrous iron.  This is good ol'e American standard that will last you 3 generations.  If you keep it clean, oiled, and cared for, your grandchildren will be cooking in this cast iron and so will their grandchildren.Recommendation is you not worry about the factory pre-seasoning and do your own seasoning.  The factory seasoning will last about 3-4 cooking and it will wear off.  Then apply own seasoning and continuously season with every cooking session.  Many youtube videos on how to season a cast iron pan.Now, I just came across a video about using soap on cast iron and I had been pleasantly surprised.  Yes, you can use soap on cast iron ( a little bit of soap and gentle wash).  Look for that video as well.  Spoiler:  basically a proper seasoning is polymerization of oil onto metal.  You all have burned oil/grease on your pots and pans that don't come off despite soap and hard scrubbing, right?  Well, if it is that difficult to get that stuff off, why do you think we continue the old saying you can't use soap on cast iron?  Why wouldn't the soap dissolve the grease right off that pots and pans you spent hours cleaning?  Hmmmm.  Think about that for a little bit.So, watch that video.  You can find it on you tube.  Anyway, I have been using a light soap and it's been fine.  Nothing is happening to the seasoning.  MAKE SURE YOUR SEASONING IS CORRECT.  You want that same layer of oil film that sticks to your pot that doesn't want to come off.  Then the soap you use to wash off food won't wash off that seasoning.  Same concept.Anyway, for the $$-- a great purchase!
title: No frill, no joke; good ole American standard quality that will last.

author: Theresa T
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2020
review_content: Gave away an old cast iron skillet years ago because I never learned how to cook in it without a stuck on mess.  After reading up and watching a few videos I decided to give it another try. Washed it with a mild dish soap (First time wash only), then “seasoned” it with Wesson vegetable oil three times. Next day made a pan of southern corn bread. Poured the batter in a hot bacon greased pan and tossed it in the oven. WOW! The best cornbread ever, and it slid right out of the pan! I’m excited to try other things. I guess the key to good results is knowing how to use the pan correctly. Watch some videos if you’ve never cooked in cast iron. Made all the difference for me.
title: I’m hooked!

author: David L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2019
review_content: It comes “pre-seasoned”, but it’s worth the effort to season it again. I use it mostly for steaks, chops, and bacon, and it works exactly as I expected. The oven-readiness is a big advantage over nonstick skillets. Cast iron can handle very hot ovens and broilers that would destroy other cookware.The silicone handle grip that comes with doesn’t fit very securely, so I don’t bother using it, preferring sturdy hot pan mittens instead. I *really* don’t want to drop this behemoth.Cleanup is reasonably easy with one of those chain-mail scrapers, plain water, and a sponge. I have a sponge that has never touched any detergent that I use. Maybe I’m paranoid, but I don’t want to risk removing the seasoning.The price is right, and the extra effort of using cast iron is well worth it.
title: Very heavy. It’s cast iron, after all
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: J.C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2019
review_content: Learn to turn the heat down, it holds heat beautifully and cooks great. Stove top to brown meat and finish it off in the oven. I own the Lodge Enamel Grill, this size skillet and a larger one. Once you get a good season on your pans and learn to cook at lower temperatures you can cook just about anything. The only thing I tend not to cook in these are things with high acid, like tomato based, lemon based foods, they are hard on your seasoning. Fry fish, scramble eggs, you have to use butter, grease of some sort. Meat, let it brown (also when frying potatoes) well on one side before turning. People move stuff around the pan too quick and things stick, also if you don't have a good seasoning. These can last 100 years if taken care of properly. Once you learn all the things you can make with cast iron, (check out this cook book; ( https://www.amazon.com/Southern-Cast-Iron-Cookbook-Comforting/dp/1939754089/ref=sr_1_2_sspa?keywords=cast+iron+cook+book&qid=1547855010&sr=8-2-spons&psc=1 )you will always want to have one.
title: Love Cast Iron

author: Todd Davis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2019
review_content: This is my first cast-iron pan. I was always scared of using cast iron because I grew up on consumer-grade pans with non-stick coatings and lightweight metals. Those lesser quality pans always seem to degrade quickly however. The non-stick coating wears off, the pans buckle and warp, and I end up throwing them away and buying another, rinse and repeat ad nauseum.The Lodge pan is solid, and heavy. I did my due diligence and read up on how to use and care for a iron pan, and to be honest, it is no worse than taking care of any other pan. It cleans up super easily, and after a few uses, it has proven to be just about as non-stick as any of my non-stick pans, but cooks better, more evenly, browns nicely, and cleanup is a breeze. I clean it like any other pan, with some mild dish soap and a plastic scrub, dry it, then apply a very light coat of oil before storing it. That's it. No magic. It just works, and it is such a joy to cook on. If you've been shying away from getting a good cast iron pan, I wholeheartedly recommend this one as a good starter. This will cover most of your daily cooking needs.
title: Great quality pan
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: JL
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2020
review_content: I’ve gone through several cast iron pans. This one is by far the best one. I bought this late 2018 and still use it at least 3-4 times a week. It really brings out the flavor of every dish. I even made deep dish pizza with it. Every kitchen needs to have this pan! Make sure you season it after every wash. If yours comes with a silicon holder, don’t use it. It’s too dangerous to use: it doesn’t fit well and the handle gets very hot. The only other complaint I have is that I wish the handle is a bit longer and wider.
title: Best Cast Iron Pan
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 12-InchVerified Purchase

author: consumer187
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2020
review_content: My first cast iron skillet and boy is she big. I can fry 4 or 5 pieces of chicken at a time in shallow oil barely using a 1/2 inch. Beats deep frying and outside of a "little" special care she will last us the rest of my days (I'm 51). Cleanup is a breeze tbh, nothing sticks. But I do wipe all water off of her and leave her on a burner on low heat to dry her (as iron holds onto water without heat). Rub a smidge of Flax or Bacon grease on it, coat her all over and let her cool down and store away so she don't rust. This size 13.25 is heavy but even with my bad back I can get her to and from and she is worth it. I have two grown men and a Golden Retriever to feed, she is a dream skillet.
title: We call this mama's Big Black Betty

author: Olympic View
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2020
review_content: It's not often you can find something that just works as intended, will last a lifetime, and at a good price.  There may be lighter ones out there, or some kind of better "design" like a double spout, whatever - save yourself some time and just go with the reliable standard - Lodge.  Their YouTube videos are also very informative.  But you have to learn how to maintain and season a cast iron pan if you're looking at cast iron - there is no skipping that part.  But once you get the hang of it you'll wonder how you ever cooked without one.  We use ours both in the kitchen and out camping.  We have them in different sizes and shapes too (check out the dutch oven for camping).  You cannot go wrong with Lodge.
title: The Gold Standard

author: Geo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2021
review_content: I have happily used a Lodge 12” skillet for years. Occasionally I have wished that I had a little more space in the pan.  So I purchased this 13 inch pan.  There is nothing wrong with this pan.  It is excellent quality.  However, it is much much heavier than the 12”.  I am a fairly robust male but maneuvering this pan with one hand is fairly difficult especially if using a pot holder or OvGlove which have some give.  Be prepared to use two hands, one on each side either using two gloves or pot holders or get the silicon handles for both handles.  Just sayin’, it’s heavy.
title: It’s  Heavy

author: Trina Perkins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2020
review_content: I thought I was getting it from Amazon .. but the package came from Walmart and the refund is supposed to come from ZDeals. That being said .. some nasty brown stuff was poured all over the air bumpers, the skillet label and into the bowl of the skillet. I forgot to take a photo of the skillet before I tried seasoning it to see if it'd come off and while the surface "stuff" came off afterwards .. you could still see where it had been. Since there was no identifying it .. I have asked for a prepaid return label and can only hope they won't turn around and resell it to someone!
title: What WAS that stuff?

author: Alex M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2017
review_content: This has very quickly become my favorite skillet. The 8-inch is VERY small, but it's perfect for searing meat or cooking small portions of something in a pan that you don't have to baby with gentle sponges and nylon utensils. It's very sturdy, very heavy, and retains heat extremely well. And since it's cast iron, you can scrape metal utensils over it all day and, short of annoying the heck out of your significant other, it won't be any worse for the wear.The only big ding I can give it, and the reason for 4 stars instead of the perfect 5, is that the "pre-seasoned" label was an absolute lie. When I first got it I tested it with an egg (which I didn't expect to work particularly well anyway), and it was an absolute disaster. After I managed to get all of it cleaned off, I decided to try a pork cutlet instead, and it was also a disaster. Completely stuck to the bottom and requiring a lot of scraping to get unstuck (and then flipped and stuck again).Once I realized that the "pre-seasoning" was either not done or just terribly done, I spent an afternoon seasoning it 4 times in a row in the oven. Total time was about 5 hours, but "my" time was about 5 minutes. Wipe some oil on it, put it in the oven for an hour, let it cool. Wipe some more oil on, another hour in the oven, repeat.Lodge has very good instructions for seasoning it on their website so I had no trouble at all. And while 4 seasonings back-to-back may have been a bit overkill, I'm happy to say that after months of use and abuse this thing is still holding up like a champ. I use a "chainmail" scrubber to get stuck on bits off, the scratchy side of a sponge for softer things, and *gasp* even the occasional dash of *soap*! And yet it just keeps on working flawlessly with no need to re-season it.Just don't leave it sitting out wet, and don't put it in the dishwasher, and you should be fine for years.
title: This has very quickly become my favorite skillet. The 8-inch is VERY small

author: Theresa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2021
review_content: I have another Lodge pre-seasoned cast iron pan that I love, so I ordered this one to have a second size. I’m disappointed that it arrived scratched and rusted on the one side. I tried to clean it and run the pre-season process in the oven, but it didn’t fix the rust. I don’t want to scratch off the original pre-seasoning while trying to fix it. I contacted Lodge and they said it will correct itself over time as long as I keep it oiled, but it’s disappointing receiving a flawed product that I have to fix. Learned my lesson ordering this online.
title: Arrived scratched and rusted
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 10.25-InchVerified Purchase

author: ilene b.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2021
review_content: I have read that cast iron is one of the healthiest to cook in - - versus some many that are coated with numerous coatings.  I love my cast iron.  This small skillet was pre-seasoned and I have no problem with anything sticking.  I have a larger skillet and also the 14" Lodge cast iron wok that I also love.  They all work wonderfully on my new precision induction cooktop.  This small skillet is great for breakfast eggs - - and I have even used it in my air fryer - - for a quick bake skillet breakfast.
title: Great little skillet

author: stevef
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2021
review_content: Unless you have strong hands, I can't recommend it. It's heavy, and even as a man myself, it's takes some strength to hold it up in my left hand, which is my weakest since I'm right handed. The silicone sleeve is loose fitting, so doesn't feel very secure when using, but better than nothing. Knowing what I know now, I'd buy the pan without the sleeve for less money and use a good fitting oven mit. I only use it for eggs. Once it's seasoned(I use olive oil), the egg mostly comes off without sticking too bad. Takes some scraping, and there's always a little left.
title: heavy
verified: Style: Skillet with Handle HolderSize: 10.25-InchVerified Purchase

author: Strwbery
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2019
review_content: I have two other Lodge pieces; a Dutch oven and a larger cooking pan, love them both.I bought a smaller pan for quick snacks like a burger.This 6.5 pan I found dangerous. I use silicon pot holders which are great for protecting my hands from being burned and are thin enough to grasp any handle, except this one.The pan itself arrived chipped on the rim.  It was missing the black coating. I contacted Lodge and was told it was ok because after time and use the seasonings would protect it. I was not happy but didn’t bother arguing.The cooking area also had a large indent and VERY bumpy area.  I have never had this problem before.  I understand that this type of cookware will have an uneven surface but this was overkill.Because of these multiple problems I decided to add the pan to my recyclables and threw it out.I also felt that Lodge customer service was not responsive to my concerns.  Bad customer service.
title: If you have a problem with your item, don’t expect Lodge customer service to help

author: Gerry, Las Vegas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2018
review_content: I have read a couple of reviews complaining about the Lodge pan's rough surface.  A few people referred to other pans that are WAY more expensive.  With a little effort, it's easy to smooth and re-season a Lodge pan for next to nothing.  A common drill with some inexpensive sanding pads (start at 60 grit, end at 240 grit) and in less than an hour you have a super smooth pan.  After sanding, clean in hot water and dry.  Put a light coat of flaxseed oil on the pan (dripping is too much) then bake up side down at 400 degrees for 90 minutes.  Allow to cool in oven and you have a BETTER pan than the super expensive guys.  (Photos attached of the process.)
title: If you think the finish is rough, don't spend $80 - $120 more, easy fix

author: Andrea Contento
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2021
review_content: I use this for cooking my breakfast - while you have to cut the bacon in half, that is certainly not a problem for me.  Eggs come out just right, whether scrambled, poached, or fried.  It is just the right size for one pancake or a slice of french toast.For lunch, a grilled cheese sandwich fits perfectly, as does a hamburger.Clean-up is easy with this skillet - I use Knapp cast iron wax for a slick finish, otherwise, a dab of canola or olive oil keeps it in perfect shape.  As an added bonus it is light, so it is easy to handle.
title: Perfect size for one person

author: Qsecret
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2020
review_content: I have been wanting a cast iron fry pan for a long time, I have all non-stick fry pans but love watching how the cast irons pans sear when a chef uses them on TV. I guess I was nervous about the ‘seasoning’ aspect, but since my husband grew up with his mom using cast iron, he was sure it would be fine. I haven’t looked back since I purchased this...no more freezing outside in the winter when trying to bar b q steak, I just pull out my cast iron pan! It’s fairly easy to clean and season (the hubby does that), and I do love how it sears meats.
title: Great pan

author: S. Brown
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2018
review_content: I don't use this pan very often ..  I probably could have done without it.  Just one more pan to store.  The times I have used it I have found the food does not stick..  (that is if it is seasoned after every use) It is a nice cast iron pan so if you like cooking in one this would be a good buy...Update:  well I have had this pan for a year now and I love it.  I use it all the time now.  I like that I can sear chicken on the stove and then put it in the oven to finish cooking.  is also great for steaks.
title: Good quality pan

author: Owen Hauth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2020
review_content: This is my first cast iron pan. I use it almost exclusively for many different types of food. It is easy to clean, it heats evenly, and it has held up well. Make sure to dry the pan completely and oil it after use. Do not set it on a drying rack and leave it because it may rust. The 10 1/2 inch pan fits a one dish meal for two adults.Most people opt for non stick pans because they think cast iron is intimidating or too much work, but non stick is actually more temperamental. You have to use special utensils, you have to wash it carefully, and the non stick coating quickly wears out and you have to replace the pan.With cast iron, if you keep it oiled properly, it gets easier to clean instead of wearing out.
title: Buy once, use it forever.

author: Peter Guither
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2017
review_content: Note: I got the 8" version of this pan. The dimensions are 12.75" from end to end (tip of the handle). 6.25" flat cooking surface, and 8" across at the top of the pan (8.5" side to side with the extra notches). This was important to me since I wanted to have a pan that would be large enough to cook what I needed and still be able to fit in the large toaster oven that I have. This is perfect for a single nice rib-eye steak or a 1/2 ground chuck hamburger. And oh, does it work well. Wonderfully charred outside with medium rare center is so easy with this pan.It comes pre-seasoned, and I just follow some basic maintenance of it that has kept a perfect seasoned finish. Clean with hot water and kosher salt (if I need something to help loosen any particles), put it on the burner for a couple minutes after drying to get rid of any moisture. Use a paper towel to rub on a little bit of oil before hanging it up.
title: Quality Cast Iron Skillet
